loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a soup and juice seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Mwanzo Mgumu loan group (Group code 2018). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works at her business from 12:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more meat for soup and different types of fruit for juice. She aims to prepare a lot of juice to satisfy her customers' needs. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Khadija is 30 years old, married, and has a 15-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more meat and fruit for her business

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia P., 65, is widowed with eight children. She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public, three days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~120 USD).  SPBD loans are Malia’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to buy seeds and chemicals for her vegetable garden and plantation business.

loans.use: To purchase tools (e.g., shovel, rake), garden spray and insecticide

loans.name: Ayichatou

texts.fr:
A. Ayichatou est née vers 1947 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique du BENIN. Ayichatou est veuve depuis vingt et un (21) ans; mais, Ayichatou n'a plus d'enfant à sa charge. Ayichatou est dans le commerce de divers(produits cosmétiques, pâtes alimentaires, boîtes de conserves, papiers hygiéniques, etc.)depuis son adolescence. Ayichatou a pu élever le niveau de son activité grâce aux deux prêts antérieurs qu'elle a eu de ALIDé. Ayichatou est satisfaite des services de ALIDé. Ayichatou a pour projet de continuer de développer son activité; c'est pourquoi elle sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Ayichatou A. was born around 1947 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of Benin. Ayichatou has been a widow for 21 years; however, she is no longer raising any children. Ayichatou has been selling general merchandise (cosmetics, pasta, tinned foods, toilet paper, etc.) since her adolescence.

Ayichatou has been able to raise the level of her business thanks to two prior loans that she has received through ALIDé. Ayichatou is satisfied with the services of ALIDé. Her plan is to continue to develop her business; that is why she has requested a third loan from ALIDé. The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria; its GDP per inhabitant is US$ 1,500. ALIDé offers special loans at 0% interest to very vulnerable persons and it is in a group that will soon begin to offer a micro-insurance program (health insurance) for the beneficiaries of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cases of: soap, sweet biscuits, pasta, and sugar; packages of toilet paper; tinned sardines

loans.name: Bang's Group

texts.en:
Bằng Nguyễn Thị was born in 1974 ( ID: 010114150041). Everybody in the village loves her. She is the group leader. There are 4 members in her house: her husband and two children. Her husband is a builder. Day by day, she makes wine to sell. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to buy some pigs and food for pigs. Besides her, there are 4 members in her group:

Thoa Nguyễn Thị was born in 1961 (ID: 010114150042). She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND to buy scrap metal to re-sell. She has a daily income of about 75.000 VND.

Chí Nguyễn Thị was born in 1976 ( ID: 010114150043). Every day she goes to other villages to buy scrap metal and then she re-sells it. She wants to borrow 5.450.000 VND to buy scrap metal and food for her pigs.

Nguyệt Lê Thị was born in 1972 ( ID: 010114150044). She wants to borrow 4.578.000 VND to buy vegetables to sell in the market.

Tới Nguyễn Thị was born in 1967 ( ID: :010114150045). She wants to borrow 5.886.000 VND to buy food for pigs; she will use some to buy scrap metal from farmers in other villages.

loans.use: to buy some pigs and food for pigs

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha A. K. is 44 years old and lives in Tulkrem City in Palestine.To help her family economically, she decided to open her own sewing workshop in order to support her four children of whom all are in school,  given that her husband’s income does not cover their living expenses. She wants a loan of US$ 1200 to buy sewing machines, accessories and fabrics. Aisha would like to thank you in advance for your support!

loans.use: Purchase sewing machines and accessories

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is divorced and raising two children, who are 11 and 6 years old. She owns a small store that sells various construction and finishing materials. Her store is located close to the markets and business area of the city. Good location brings many customers to Olena's store. Her monthly profit is about 6,000 UAH.

Olena has been in this business for 10 years. Being their only source of income, the business helps Olena to raise her children. Olena's goal is to fix up her apartment and improve her living conditions. Olena is an enthusiastic and hard-working person; she believes she can cope with all living problems and difficulties.

Olena would like to borrow 14,000 UAH to purchase 20 doors. Additional profit would help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase 20 doors

loans.name: Shukrani Group

texts.en:
Maryam has been a clothes (khanga) and shoes seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for three years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business from 8:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more Khanga and shoes for her business. Maryam is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Maryam is 45 years old, married, and has three children: 18, 12 and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Khadija,Safia and Kesi. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: Buy more shoes and Khanga for her business.

loans.name: Kadijat

texts.en: Kadijat is 33 years old and married with two children.  She sells building materials like paint, nails, etc.  She is requesting a loan of N60,000 to purchase more building materials to sell.  Kadijat thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more building materials to sell.

loans.name: Ore-Oluwa

texts.en: Ore-Oluwa is 32 years old and married with three children.  She sells female clothes.  Ore-Oluwa is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.  She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more female clothes to sell.

loans.name: Huyen

texts.en:
Huyền Nguyễn Thị was born in 1984. She lives at Lễ Pháp village – Tiên Dương commune – Đông Anh district- Hà Nội city.

This is her first microfinance loan. She wants to borrow 2.204.000 VND to buy some pigs. She also grows vegetables and sells in the market. Her husband works in construction and his salary helps her pay expenses for their family.

loans.use: Buy some pigs.

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr:
A. Colette est née vers 1952 à Ouidah dans le département de l'Atlantique, au Sud du Bénin. Colette est mariée, elle a cinq (5) enfants, tous déjà adultes et installés à leur propre compte. C'est depuis son enfance que Colette a été initiée au commerce par sa défunte tante auprès de qui elle est restée jusqu'à son mariage. Après son mariage, Colette s'est mise à vendre de l'huile de palme, du maïs, de la farine de manioc, de bois de chauffe et divers autres articles. Colette a eu déjà deux prêts de ALIDé qu'elle a bien remboursé et grâce auxquels elle a augmenté le niveau de son commerce. Aujourd'hui encore, Colette sollicite un prêt en vue de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Colette A. was born around 1952 in Ouidah in the Atlantique province, in the south of Bénin. Colette is married; she has 5 children, all already adults and living on their own. Since childhood, Colette was taught to sell goods by her late aunt, with whom she remained until her marriage.

After her marriage, Colette started selling palm oil, maize, manioc flour, firewood, and various other articles. Colette has already received two loans from ALIDé which she reimbursed in a timely manner and thanks to which she was able to improve her little business. Today, Colette is requesting another loan, with a view to satisfying the needs of her clientele.

The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria; its GDP per inhabitant is US$ 1,500. ALIDé offers special loans at 0% interest to very vulnerable persons and it is in a group that will soon begin to offer a micro-insurance program (health insurance) for the beneficiaries of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of jerrycans of palm oil and of a locally produced alcoholic beverage called SODABI

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Saroeun L., 53, and her husband, Heng Min, 55, live on Island of Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Married in 1979 they have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of her daughters who are silk weavers, were married but live inside the family home. Another daughter is learning tailoring skill, one son is a teacher and the other attends school. Besides her children, she also has two sons in-law and four grandchildren living with her.

Saroeun has been selling desserts at the local market for four years and she weave silk as well. Her husband raises cows. She lacks the money to purchase more silk materials to continue her weaving business. So she is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: Purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en: Adenike is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She sells drinks. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal T., 41, and her husband, Mr. Senglay Kroeung, 45, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, married in 1990 and have two daughters. One of them is in school and the other one assists her mother in their grocery business.

Sophal has been a silk weaver and selling groceries for ten years. She buys grocery items from the market in Phnom Penh for re-sale in a local market. Her husband assists his wife in selling grocery items; he used to be a policeman as well. Sophal is requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more grocery items for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for re-sale

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en: Violeta P. is 49 years old, a single mother who has 2 children and resides at Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She has a "carenderia" (cafe) business at the Public Market. Violeta is a micro-finance member and at present she's requesting a loan amounting to PHP 6,000, her second small loan.  She wants to buy ingredients such as meat, spices, and seasonings so she can add menus for her "carenderia" or eatery.  She started her business with her own little capital and manages it by herself. Her future plan for her business is to be progressive; she hopes that all her children will finish their education and become successful, having good job someday.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients such as meat, spices, and seasonings

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en:
Maryam, the one who is standing in front of the window, has owned a small restaurant in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She belongs to Maisha Imara loan group (Group code 2040). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 70. Each day she works at her business from 7:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish, potatoes, rice, and other items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Maryam is 38 years old, married, and has six children: ages 20, 18, 14, 8, 6 and one only 10 months old.

loans.use: To buy fish, potatoes, rice, and other items for her business

loans.name: Hidaya Njema Group

texts.en:
Rehema S. is a charcoal and firewood seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 50. Every day she works at her business.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Rehema S. is married, and has three children: ages 17, 13, and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanambashi and Rehema S.. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business

loans.name: Enaam

texts.en: Enaam is a 37-year-old woman, living in Al Shwaifat in Mount Lebanon. She has been working as a home-based tailor for seven years. Today, she wants to borrow US$ 1,200 in order to buy a new sewing machine and some textiles.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine and some textiles

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo A. is 48 years old and married with 3 children. She sells wines and drinks. She hopes to expand this business. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more wines and drinks to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more wines and drinks to sell

loans.name: Saheed

texts.en: Saheed A. A. is 34 years old and married 4 children. His wife sells medicines. Saheed is a barber and also sells video CDs. He is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more barbering material and video CDs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more barbering materials and VCDs to sell

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 24 year old man who lives with his wife in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Ibrahim has owned a butcher shop since 2007. He requested a loan of 1200 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase lamb for his shop. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him purchase merchandise for his shop and improve his financial situation. His clients are his friends and neighbors. Ibrahim chose his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase lamb for his butcher shop

loans.name: Muibat

texts.en: Muibat A. is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions like noodles, milk, etc. She is requesting the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is s 50 year old man who lives with his wife in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Mohammad has been selling thread and tablecloths for thirty-two years. He has requested a loan of 1,200 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his work. This is the first time that Mohammad has requested a loan.

Mohammad is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When, he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. Mohammad chose his business because of his experience in sales and he wanted to improve his family’s financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his business

loans.name: Suluaiman

texts.en: Suluaiman I. is 35 years old and married with 2 children. He has a business center where he makes photocopies and does spiral binding, laminating and typesetting for his customers.  He is requesting the loan amount of N 80,000 to purchase one photocopier and a computer. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more one photocopier and a computer

loans.name: Uyen's Group

texts.en:
Uyên Nguyễn Thị Tố was born in 1978. She has two children, and her husband works as a builder. She buys rice from the market at a low cost and resells it at her house or in her village T. earn money. She will use this loan T. boost her income by buying more rice T. sell T. another village. She has a monthly income of about 2,500,000 VND and wants T. borrow 4,142,000 VND T. purchase more rice. 

She is applying for this loan with two other women:

Chức Nguyễn Thị was born in 1967. She has a monthly income of about 2,000,000 VND and would also like T. borrow 4,142,000 VND T. buy rice T. sell.

Mầu Nguyễn Thị was born in 1961. She wants T. borrow 4,142,000 VND T. buy food for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy rice to sell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 21 year old man who lives with his parents in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Ali has owned a barber shop since 1998. Ali has requested a loan of 1,200 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and beauty products for his work. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.

Ali is special in his work because of his experience. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he had difficulty purchasing tools for his salon. Ali chose his business because he learned it through an academy. In the future, he plans on purchasing a bigger salon.

loans.use: To purchase tools and beauty products for his work

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
Haidar is a 51 year old man who lives with his wife in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Haidar has owned a grocery store since 2006. He has requested a loan of 1,200 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Haidar has requested a loan.

Haidar is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. Haidar chose his business because of his experience and he wanted to improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on enlarging his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his grocery store

loans.name: Alia

texts.en:
Alia is a 54 year old woman who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Alia has owned a grocery store. She requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. This is the first time that Alia has requested a loan. 
Alia is special in her work because she knows how to treat his clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. In the future, he plans on improving her store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her grocery store

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 47 year old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Houssein works in agriculture. Houssein requested a loan of 700 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and merchandise for his work. This is the first time that Houssein has requested a loan.

Houssein is special because he has experience. When he first started his business, he had financial issues. Houssein chose his business because he wanted to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and merchandise for his work

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 27-year-old man who lives in Tyre, Southern Lebanon. Ali has owned a coffee shop since 1999. He also serves narguileh (also known as shisha in Egypt). Narguileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Narguileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East and is beginning to gain popularity in the U.S., Europe and other countries. Ali requested a loan of $1500 US from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his coffee shop. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan.

Ali is special in his work because people feel comfortable coming to his place. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When he first started, he didn’t have enough cash to purchase all the necessary tools and machines for his shop. He decided on doing this business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on enlarging his shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for a coffee shop

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en:
Youssef is a 51 year old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Youssef has owned a grocery store since 2000. He requested a loan of 1,300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Youssef has requested a loan.

Youssef is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. Youssef chose his business because of his experience and he wanted to improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on expanding his store.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his grocery store

loans.name: Hala Group

texts.en:
The group name is Hala; it is made of three ladies, who are living in the region of the Bekaa, Lebanon.

Rana is a 30 year old married woman with two children. Rana has been selling accessories from her home for two years. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is the first time that Rana has requested a loan.

Rana is speciA. in her work because she sells nice accessories. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had financiA. issues. Rana started her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on expanding her work.

Rajaa is a 43 year old married woman. She has been selling shoes for four years. Rajaa requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her business. This is the first time that Rajaa has requested a loan.

Rajaa is speciA. in her work because she likes what she does and knows how to treat her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. Rajaa chose her business because she has experience. In the future, she plans on expanding her business.

Hala is a 40 year old married woman. She has owned an accessory shop for four years. Hala requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her work. This is the first time that Hala has requested a loan.

Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When Hala first started her business, she didn’t have the startup capitA.. She chose her business because of her experience. In the future, Hala plans on expanding her business.

About Group Loans:
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individuA. loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Abdukodir

texts.en:
G. Abdukodir first applied to MicroInvest in 2007 for a business development loan. His loans have enabled him to improve his fresh and dried fruit selling business and overcome tough market competition. He lives in the B. G. region of Tajikistan, but travels to Khujand every day to trade in the local bazaar, Panjshanbe.

He trades produce from the collective farm where he also works as bookkeeper. He keeps prices low by working directly with suppliers, rather than agents. Abdukodir is applying to KIVA for a six-month business support loan of $325 (1200 TJS) to expand his trading area.

loans.use: To expand his fruit selling business.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a 29-year-old woman who lives in Bekaa with her husband and their six children. Samira has owned a chicken's snack shop for four years. Samira requested a loan of $1500 US from A. Majmoua in order to purchase soft drinks and other merchandise for her snack shop. This is her third cycle and she has always paid on time.

Her previous loans helped her improve her snack shop and her financiA. situation. Her clients can be anyone from her region. She decided on doing this business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans on improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks and other merchandise for a snack shop

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 55 year old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their seven children. Husein has been working as an agriculturalist and as a taxi driver since 1999. Husein requested a loan of 1,500 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work and do some maintenance work on his car. This is the first time that Husein has requested a loan.

Husien is special because he is an active man who does his best to improve his family’s income. Husein decided on starting his businesses because he wants the best for his family as well as to answer his family’s need. In the future, he plans on improving his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work and do some maintenance work on his taxi

loans.name: Ty

texts.en:
Ty S., 25, and his wife, Sovanary Khan, 29, were married in 2002 and have two sons who are syoung. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Ty has been selling sandwiches on baguettes in his village for five years. His wife is a garment factory worker. The couple also grows rice. Ty’s is requesting a loan of $200 to repair his house.

loans.use: Repair his house.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is 35 years old and married, with four children aged 15, 11, 6 and 5. She also cares for four additional dependants.

Fatma has sold clothes and snacks in Zanzibar’s Mikunguni neighborhood for six years. She belongs to the Tawaqal group loan (Group code 2018). She works every day and currently earns an average monthly profit of $175.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more clothes and snacks to sell. She is hoping that this loan will enable her to boost profitability and expand her business, so that she can pay school fees for her children and save money for future use.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 60-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their nine children. Ahmad has been working in agriculture for twelve years. Ahmad requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan.

Ahamd is special because he has experience. Ahmad decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa T., 56, is a widow with six children: three sons and three daughters. One of her sons is a motor taxi driver while another works in a Phnom Penh restaurant, and the third one is in school. She lives along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Having learned the skill from her parents, Channa has been a farmer for 15 years.  She is now requesting a loan of $300 to build a shelter for her daughter to continue her business of selling grocery items, sugar cane juice and soft drinks.

loans.use: To build a shelter for her daughter to sell sugar cane juice and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: New dry fruits purchasing.

loans.name: Sreypov

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov U. (who is in the picture above with her mother and children) is 34 years old and her husband, Mr. Veasna Teang, is 36 years old. They live in a small village that is a suburb of Phnom Penh.  They were married in 2000 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. One of her children attends school and the other two are still small. 

Sreypov has been selling grocery items for ten years. Her husband has been a garment factory worker for over five years. She hopes to purchase more grocery items for her stock as she prepares to sell on the Khmer New Year holiday, because on that day, the price of grocery items will be high. She is requesting her first loan of $500 to make the purchases and to buy an ice machine.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale and to buy an ice machine.

loans.name: Thida

texts.en:
Mrs. Thida C. is sixty-five years old and a widow with four children, three sons and one daughter. The daughter has full-time employment in a company in Phnom Penh. One of her children is autistic, one son assists his mother in her business, and the other one is in school. The family lives in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Thida has been selling rice for ten years. She buys the rice from the market in Phnom Penh and resells it at the Chamkar Dong market. She earns a profit of about $37.50 a day. Thiday hopes to expand her business, so she is requesting her first loan of $400 to purchase more rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice to sell.

loans.name: Muborack

texts.en: D. Muborack first applied to the Kiva field partner, MicroInvest, in 2009, and presented herself as an honest and reliable client. She is twenty-six years old and lives in Khuhand. She is engaged in commercial service and trade involving food products. She has worked as the bookkeeper of this business for thirteen years. Muborack is asking for a business development loan of $425 to be used to import vegetable oil from Iran. She thanks Kiva for its support and sends her best wishes.

loans.use: To import vegetable oil from Iran

loans.name: Sroin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroin K. is forty-four years old and lives with her husband, Mr. Nheb Eng, who is forty-eight. Their home is in a small village across the MeK. River and about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.  They were married in 1982 and have two sons. One son is married and lives outside the family home and the other attends school. 

Sroin and her husband are rice farmers. Besides farming, Mr. Nheb Eng is also a fisherman. Sroin is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase some spare parts for repairing their plow.  They use the plow for farming and rent it out to neighbors.  They also use it to carry firewood that they sell.

loans.use: To buy repair parts for a plow.

loans.name: Simean

texts.en:
Mrs. Simean T. is thirty-six years old and a widow with two children, one son and one daughter. Both of her children are in primary school. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia.
 
Simean has been growing vegetables for four years.Beside of farming she also has another business is a basket and bag weaver (show in the picture). She takes one kind of edible aquatic plant to dry with the sun and take it to weave bags or baskets. Her house was built on her sister’s land, but now she has her own land so is asking for a loan of $500 to move her house.

loans.use: To move her house.

loans.name: Ishalla Kher Group

texts.en:
Mwanaisha has been a charcoal and firewood seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for ten years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. She works at her business every day. She is requesting her second loan from the Kiva field partner, BRAC Tanzania, so that she can buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business, pay school fees for her children and save money for the future.  

Mwanaisha is forty-five years old, married, and has five children, ages twenty-four, twenty-three, nineteen, eighteen and thirteen. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mkasi and Zainab. Each of these women have their own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Pili

texts.en:
Pili has owned a small restaurant in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She belongs to Mapatano group loan (Group code 2070). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $220. Each day she works at her business. 

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items in order to expand her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase, she will be able to grow her business, and she will be able to save money for future use.

Pili is 34 years old, married, and has four children aged 18 years, 16 years, 11 years, and 7 months. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more items in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambo K., forty-four, and her husband, Mr. Horn He, thirty-six, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1991 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. Two of the children are in secondary school and the other two are in primary school. 
 
Sambo has been a silk-weaver since she was sixteen years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then distributes it for resale at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a construction worker since 1986. Sambo is requesting her second loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Banin

texts.en:
Mr. Banin H., sixty-eight, and his wife, Mrs. Sokea Chhom, fifty-two, were married in 1995 and have two sons, both of whom attend school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mrs. Sokea Chhom has been selling dessert in her village for six years: it’s a skill she learned from her parents. Banin has been growing rice for thirty years. He is asking for his first loan of $350 to use for growing rice and to purchase a water pump.

loans.use: For growing rice and to buy a water pump.

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: A sewing machine is used by Mrs. Soeurn K. for sewing clothes to earn a living. She, at age fifty-three, is a widowed mother who has given birth to six children. Five of them are students who help her in her business when they are not studying, and the other one is married and lives independently. To help with the family's daily expenses, K.'s oldest child is employed as a boat driver for tourists. The family's living conditions are not comfortable because their house is old and breaks down frequently. Because of this problem, K. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house. The remainder of the loan will be used as business capital.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Vira

texts.en:
Mr. Vira U., fifty-nine, and his wife, Mrs. Sa-um Say, fifty-three, were married in 1975 and have seven children, four sons and three daughters. The eldest son is a construction worker, one daughter is a garment factory worker, one son is a security guard, another son assists his parents in farming, and the other two children attend school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Vira and his wife are farmers. They grow many kinds of food crops, sU. as taros and papayas. In addition to farming, Mrs. Sa-um Say has been weaving scarves for twenty years as well. Vira is requesting his second loan of $1,000 to use for farming.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Raya

texts.en:
Raya has been a fruit-seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. She belongs to the Mshikamano group loan (Group code 2016).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. She works at her business every day.  

She is requesting her third loan from the Kiva field partner, BRAC Tanzania, so that she can buy more fruit for her business. She is hoping that through this loan her profit will increase, and she will be able to expand her business and save money for the future.

Raya is forty-seven years old, married, and has five children, ages twenty-six, twenty-four, nineteen, fifteen and eleven.

loans.use: To buy fruit for her business

loans.name: Sreyphun Ton Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreyphun T. was selected to be a group leader by the group members for a loan from Maxima. In the group there are two families including hers. The entire group is living in a small village across Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

1-Mrs. Sreyphun T., 31, and her husband, Mr. Soksamphea Morm, 36, were married in 1991 and have three children; one son and two daughters. Two of their children attend school and another one is still young. Sreyphun has been a silk weaver for fourteen years; it’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman who then sells them in the Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been growing vegetables for sixteen years. Sreyphun is requesting her first loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

2-Mrs. Sreyphin T., 37, and her husband, Mr. Horn Chhit, 44, were married in 1993 and have no children yet. Sreyphin and her husband are silk weavers. They sell their finished products to the middleman who then sells them in the Phnom Penh market. She is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en:
I. Nazira applied for her first loan in 2003 and she is of an active client of MicroInvest who trusts our loan program and works tightly with us. Nazira lives in Khujand and she is married with four children.

Nazira is engaged in commercial service and she sells women’s wear. She has a good assortment which she brings from Kyrgyz Republic where she goes twice per month.

Nazira applies to Kiva for a business support loan of 3800 STJ for 10 months for importing seasonal wear and for supporting an increase in business turnover. Nazira thanks Kiva for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To import seasonal women's wear

loans.name: Hadia

texts.en:
Hadia is 48 years old, married, and has three children: ages 34, 32 and 24. She also cares for one additional dependent.

Hadia has been a fish and charcoal seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. She belongs to Hatutaki shari group loan (Group code 2051). She works at her business daily and currently earns an average monthly profit of $50.

Hadia is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more fish and charcoal for her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

loans.use: To buy more fish and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila is a 43-year-old married woman with one child living in Rachaya in Bekaa valley. She has owned a clothing shop called "Leila’s Shop" since 2002.

Today, Leila wants to borrow $1,200 to increase her inventory in order to develop her shop.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cows for raising

loans.name: Chanyean

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanyean T., 30, and her husband, Mr. Heng Men, 36, who live on an island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 2000 and have two children: a young son and daughter. Besides her children, her mother also lives with her. 
 
Chanyean has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then distributes them to sell in market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has constructed beds for a living for ten years. Chanyean is requesting her first loan of $150 to purchase the wooden materials needed to construct more beds.

loans.use: To purchase wooden materials to construct beds.

loans.name: Jerjes

texts.en: Jerges is a 48-year-old single man living in A. Mansoura in Bekaa valley. He has owned a mini market for 14 years, which serves the nearby areas. Jerges wants to borrow $1,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his mini market business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Raya

texts.en:
Raya is a business woman, she is 32 years old, married and has five children. She has rented a room to show television programs in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the past 3 years. She belongs to the Tumekinai group loan (Group code 2008). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works 12 hours a day at her business.  

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can expand her business by adding another television and renting a another room. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to save money for future use.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeun T., 41, and her husband, Mr. Sitha Luch, 43, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1989 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their sons is a cobbler in a shoe factory, one daughter is a garment factory worker and two other children attend school.

Soeun is a farmer. Her husband has been a construction worker since 1989; he works in Phnom Penh. Soeun is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase construction materials to build her house.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to build her house

loans.name: Many

texts.en:
Mrs. Many P., 32, and her husband, Mr. Sen Samrith, 42, who live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1999 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of their children attends school and the other two are still young. 
 
Many has been weaving and raising pigs since 2000. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then distributes them to sell in market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a policeman for fifteen years. She is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to add with her own money to buy neighboring land to expand her property.

loans.use: To add with her own money to buy neighboring land to expand her property.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroeun N., 55, and his wife, Mrs. Sava Pun, 52, were married in 1976 and have six children: two sons and four daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home and the other four children are in school. The family lives along national road about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Saroeun and his wife have been farming for twenty-seven years. They grow rice and cauliflower. The couple don't have enough capital to use for their farm and that is  why Saroeun is asking for his second loan of $1,000 to use for growing rice and cauliflower.

loans.use: To use for growing rice and cauliflower.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal N., 37, and her husband, Mr. Sakhoeun EE, 41, who live on an Island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh were married in 1997 and have two children: one son who is in school and one young daughter.

Sophal has been a silk weaver for ten years. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then takes them to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sakhoeun EE has been a farmer for ten years as well. Sophal is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase silk material, to set up a loom and to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase silk material, to set up a loom, and to repair her house.

loans.name: Savy

texts.en:
Mrs. Savy H., 44, and her husband, Mr. Sam-ath Un, 48, have seven children: two sons and five daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home; one son is a car driver for a Tourist Service in Phnom Penh; one daughter is a garment factory worker and another one is in school. The family lives along a national road about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Savy has been selling Cambodian cakes for two years; she buys them from the Koki market for resale in her village. Her husband is a car driver for a Tourist Service in Phnom Penh. Savy is asking for a loan of $1,000 to build a fence around of her house.

loans.use: To build a fence around of her house.

loans.name: Thoem

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoem K., 43, and her husband, Mr. Sokha Hing, 55, who live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1980 and have three sons. The eldest son is a car repairer and the other two are in school. 

Thoem has been selling Cambodian cakes for twenty years. She buys ingredients from the market in Phnom Penh to make the cakes for sale in her village. Her husband has been a construction worker for two years. She grinds rice into rice flour by hand. This is too hard for her so she is asking for a loan of $150 to purchase a machine to grind rice.

loans.use: To purchase a machine to grind rice into rice flour.

loans.name: Sanam

texts.en:
Sanam I., married with nine children, lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan where, like many others in the area, she is engaged in the livestock business. With 40 years of experience, Sanam makes excellent sour milk products that she sells in the local bazaar to many repeat customers.
	
She is now requesting a loan of 1600 STJ for six months to purchase special milk production equipment. Sanam thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To purchase special milk production equipment.

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
K. Mahbuba is a school teacher by professional background but she had to start her business because a teacher’s salary is too low. Mahbuba is engaged in street selling (sunflower seed, packages, etc.).

Mahbuba wants to earn money in order to start a serious business opening a national restaurant, so she is ready to work hard. She knows many people who, thanks to their hard work, were able to open a serious business.

Today Mahbuba applies to Kiva for business financial support in the loan of 2,000 STJ to purchase ice-cream and drinks for the coming season. She thanks Kiva for its support.

loans.use: To purchase ice-cream and drinks for resale

loans.name: Saidniso

texts.en:
M. Saidniso has applied for her first loan with MicroInvest in 2009 but she has shown herself to be a serious and reliable client. Saidniso lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and she is married with a pretty little child.

Saidniso is engaged in the selling of sweets (candies) and sugar in the local bazaar. She works with direct suppliers from Iran and so sells at lower prices than the bazaar prices. She has been engaged in this business for 5 years.

Saidniso is applying to Kiva with the request of a business development loan of 1,600 STJ for 6 months to import a new assortment from Uzbekistan. This will make her assortment better and increase the business turnover.

Saidniso thanks Kiva for assisting with small business development and support.

loans.use: To import a new assortment from Uzbekistan

loans.name: Fuad

texts.en:
Fuad is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region, settled in Fizuli region Kurdmahmudlu village. He was born in 1964, is married and has four children.

Five years ago Fuad started his taxi business. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for his taxi to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Tufa

texts.en:
U. Tufa lives in Khujand and she is married with four children. She is a loving mother who does everything to ensure that her children will be happy in their future.

Tufa is a school teacher but she is also engaged in business, selling women’s wear. She works with her sister, who brings the goods from Uzbekistan, and she sells it in the week-end bazaar. It is a joint family business.

Tufa applies to Kiva with the request of a business support loan of 2,500 STJ for 8 months for importing new seasonal wear and to increase business turnover. She thanks Kiva for its support and invites you to Tajikistan.

loans.use: To import new seasonal women's wear

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of rice and dried beans and other ingredients for cooked food

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing a dryer and hair extensions for re-sale

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
N. Rano has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2004 when she first applied for a business development loan. Rano started the business practically from the scratch and, thanks to the previous loans, she could succeed in the business in spite of hard competition.

Rano lives in Khujand and trades in the biggest local bazaar. Rano sells food products. She is a very kind woman. Despite the fact that she single-handedly brings up three children, she is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work hard to ensure a good future for her children.

Rano applies to Kiva for business financial support with a business support loan of 4,100 STJ for 4 months for importing seasonal wares (ice-cream and drinks). Rano thanks Kiva for its support of small business development.

loans.use: To import seasonal wares (ice-cream and drinks)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase a hair dryer and hair extensions for re-sale

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret K. is currently in the business of selling bread and tea at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to buy more tables and chairs. Margret is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 4 children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a big hotel.

In 2007 BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more tables and chairs for better space for the customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing sacks of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia O. has cultivated cereals and grown vegetables and grapes for several years already. She owns 2.3 ha of land and 0.8 ha of Moldova vine. The production is commercialized on both the local market and the market in Cahul. She works at this small business together with her husband. Her long-term plan is to purchase more land near a water source in order to grow more vegetables and grapes. This business seems to be one of importance for Eugenia, as it covers 60% of the family’s expenses.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty T. currently sells onions and is requesting a loan to buy cooking oil and onions to sell. Betty is 25 years old and is single. Betty does not have children, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop. In 2007 BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil and onions to sell

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en: Firuza U. is 30 years old, and she is married with 3 children. Firuza lives in a big house with her parents and brothers. Firuza opened a trade outlet inside her home and trades food products. She has been engaged in the business of food trading for 14 years and knows the specifications by season. Firuza applied to Kiva for a business support loan of 1600 STJ in order to purchase drinks from a factory. She thanks Kiva for its support.

loans.use: To purchase drinks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: upgrade his garage and restock his spare parts store

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha S. is currently in the business of selling beans, cooking oil, onions, and cabbage and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Asha is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. In 2007 BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing food ingredients and upgrading her bar

loans.name: Rasim

texts.en:
This young man was born in 1983. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, now settled in the Fuzuli region, in the Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. He is single. Three years ago he started this business.

Rasim repairs tires. He is enjoying his business. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy the necessary things for repairing tires and twenty tires for sale so that he will be able to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy the necessary things for repairing tires and  20 tires for sale

loans.name: Khodor

texts.en:
Khodor is 40-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Khodor owns an electrical shop. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Khodor has requested a loan.

Khodor is special in his work because he knows how to treat his customers and he is the only one in his region. His customers are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the start-up capital. Khodor decided on doing his business because of his experience and because he wanted to improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on improving his shop.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
Houssein is a 32-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife. Houssein has been working as an electrical and home repairman. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Houssein has requested a loan.

Houssein is special in his field because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capital. Houssein decided on doing this business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his shop.

loans.use: Purchase tools for work

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther G. is 29 years old and married without a child. She hopes to have a child some day. She sells medicine and provisions. She is a hardworking woman.

Esther is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine and provisions to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bread and is requesting a loan to stock more charcoal to sell. Susan is 35 years old and is married; her husband is a policeman. She has 3 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat A. is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She sells drinks. She is requesting for the loan amount of 70,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase drinks for resale

loans.name: Tororo Road Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Rehema is aged 31 years, married with 8 children and 1 step-child. She buys foodstuffs (hotel items like bananas, rice, milk, meat, fruits, sweet potatoes, cassava) and she has been in her business for 7 years. She is active, manages to take care of her family as well as herself, and helps pay the children's school fees. Her dream is to buy some land and construct tenant houses to help her kids in future.

loans.use: To purchase food for resale

loans.name: Awolola

texts.en: Awolola is 52 years old and married with 5 children. She sells provisions and medicines. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more medicines and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and medicines to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan W. is currently in the business of selling food at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more beans, flour, and vegetables for the resturant.  Susan is 20 years old and married with no children.  Her husband is a driver.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Tope

texts.en: Tope is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She sells lumber and hopes to expand this business.  She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more lumber to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more lumber to sell

loans.name: Afde N°1 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°1  ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Parcelles Assainies U2 (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de tissus et des habits. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de tissus et des habits. Les tissus et les habits sont vendus en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de renforcer leur commerce en faisant le stockage de tissus et habits.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°1 group have an average age of 40 and live in big traditional extended families in the Parcelles Assainies U2 neighborhood (Thiès region). They met through ties of neighborhood and kinship. They have almost the same business selling cloth and clothing. They are very much sought after in their businesses.

In order to improve the quality of their service and expand their businesses, the members of this confidence group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC, with whom they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan has been correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to buy a large quantity of fabric and clothing. The fabric and clothing will be sold retail, for cash, in the big marketplace of Thiès. They each hope to make an average profit of 30,000 F CFA during this loan cycle; the money will be used to cover the needs of their extended family, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Their ambition is to expand their business inventories of cloth and clothing.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering their little businesses

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angelina B. is a 57-year-old mother of three. Her husband, Florencio, is a farmer who works a small parcel of land. She grows vegetables to help support the family. She is very fortunate to send her youngest daughter to college on their small income. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital. She applied for this loan to buy pigs for fattening and to buy fish for resale. Her family works together in order to grow their business. She dreams of expanding her piggery in the future in order to supply pigs in the market.

loans.use: To buy pigs for fattening and to buy fish for retail

loans.name: Dure

texts.en:
Dure A. currently sells onions, tomatoes and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Dure is 32 years old, married, and has one child who doesn't go to school. Her husband is a driver. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop

loans.name: Adewale

texts.en:
Adewale is 35 years old and married with four children. He sells secondhand electronics like televisions and CD players.

Adewale is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more secondhand electronics to sell. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand electronics to sell

loans.name: Sakirat

texts.en:
Sakirat B. is 40 years old and married with two children. She sells foodstuffs like tomatoes paste, spices and provisions. She is a LAPO client.

She is requesting a loan of N60,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Afde N°2 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°2  ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de tissu et de mercerie. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de tissus et patte d’arachide. Les tissus et la patte d’arachide sont vendus en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°2 group have an average age of 40 and live in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district (Thiès region). They met because of being neighbors or related to each other. They have almost the same business: selling cloth and sewing supplies. They are much sought after in this activity.

Intending to improve the quality of their services and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the group confidence decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC with whom they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan was correctly reimbursed. They intend to use this loan to make a significant addition to their inventory of cloth and peanut butter. The cloth and peanut butter are sold retail, for cash, in the big market of Thiès. They each hope to make an average profit of 30,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover necessities for their extended family, with any remainder reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering their little businesses

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with one son, who is seven years old. She has a retail business selling cosmetics. Her working capital is 2,000 UAH; her monthly net profit is 1,300 UAH. A specific of this business is that it has a high turnover.

Olena enjoys selling this particular type of product very much. She has been in this business for nine years. The business does not just help her customers to take care of their bodies, but also helps Olena to take care of her family.

Olena would like to borrow 3,100 UAH to increase her inventory. This will help her to earn more profit and improve her family living conditions.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Afde Numero 14 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 14 ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Parcelles Assainies à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent plusieurs activités, par exemple, vente de bijoux, parfum et habillement et aussi vente de crème glacée, jus etc.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de marchandises.  Les habits des femmes en Afrique de L’Ouest font un parti de la culture essentiel, et toutes les femmes port les vêtements très colorants, donc le commerce des habillements et des bijoux marche bien. Il fait très chaud a Thiès, alors il y a beaucoup de demande pour la crème glacée et le jus aussi.  Les marchandises du groupe sont vendues en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000CFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women of the Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 14 group have an average age of 35 and live in big traditional extended families in the "Parcelles Assainies" neighborhood in Thiès, a town 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

They met through living in the same neighborhood or being related. They have various businesses, for example, selling costume jewelry, perfume and clothing, and also ice cream, juice, etc. They have a lot of experience and are much sought after in these activities.

Wishing to improve the quality of their services and expand their businesses, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They have already received one group loan through IMCEC and have reimbursed it correctly. They intend to use this loan to build up their stocks of merchandise.

Women's clothing in West Africa is a part of essential culture, and all women wear brightly colored clothing, so the sales of clothing and jewelry are going strong. It is very hot in Thiès, so there is plenty of demand for ice cream and juice as well. The merchandise of this group is sold retail, for cash, in the big market of Thiès.

They hope to make an average profit of 30,000 F CFA during this loan cycle which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover family needs, investing the rest back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of jewelry, clothing, perfume, juice, and ice cream for re-sale

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice E. sells beer and local brew and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Alice is 27 years old, married, and has no children. Her husband is a peasant. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a bus for her business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar

loans.name: Matanat

texts.en:
Matanat was born in 1961. She is single. Matanat is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan's Fuzuli town, now resettled in the Fuzuli region, in the town of Horadiz.

Matanat has 5 years of experience in the poultry business. Now she wants a loan of AZN 2000 to buy 20 turkeys, 20 geese, and some hens for expanding her poultry business.

loans.use: To buy turkeys, geese, and hens

loans.name: Boris

texts.en:
Boris is 63 years old. He lives with his wife in a private house in Beregovo. He sells various home products in his kiosk located at the central market. Boris has been in this business for 5 years. The good location of his kiosk, large assortment of goods, and low prices bring many customers in. Moreover, the business of selling small home products does not have seasonal ups and downs. It enables Boris to have a stable income. 

Boris would like to borrow 6,500 Ukranian Hryvna to increase the assortment of his goods. He came to the conclusion that a larger assortment would enable more people to purchase what they need at one location. Thus the assortment is the key factor for his business.

loans.use: To increase the variety of goods he sells

loans.name: Kuko

texts.en: Kuko A. is a door fabricator and he makes burglary proof doors as well as iron water tanks. He is 46 years old and married with 4 children. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 Nairas to purchase fabricating materials like panels, rods and electrodes, etc. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fabricating materials for doors

loans.name: Nema

texts.en: Nema M. is a 45-year-old mother of three. Her husband, Noli, is a utility worker. She raises pigs and sells fish and vegetables in the village to support the needs of the family. She applied for this loan to buy a motor engine for the boat she wants to establish for her son Peter, who graduated college and wishes to have a job to support his parents, especially in the education of his sister and younger brother. She wants to save money to establish a bigger fishing boat in the future.

loans.use: To buy motor engine for pump boat

loans.name: Kaseen

texts.en: Kaseen is a furniture maker. He is 45 years old and married with five children. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nairas to purchase more wood to make furniture to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase wood to make furniture

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita B. currently sells bread and is requesting a loan to buy more bread to sell. Rita is 27 years old and is married to a soldier. She has one child who doesn't attend school. With the extra profits from her business, she hopes to be able to build a house for the family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bread to sell

loans.name: Afde N°3 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°3  ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de poissons et légumes. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de poissons et légumes. Les poissons et légumes sont vendus en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE No. 3” is composed of five women who average 40 years of age living in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district (Thiès region). They know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling fish and vegetables. They are in high demand in this business.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC, with which they are now on their second solidarity loan (group loan). Their first loan was correctly repaid.

The group members plan to use this loan to build up a sizable stock of fish and vegetables, which are sold retail in cash transaction at the Grand Thiès marketplace. Each group member hopes to realize an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster their business

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke O. sells clothes and bags. She is 42 years old and married with four children. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 Nairas to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel O. sells poultry supplies like plastic and paper egg trays, poultry feeders, etc. He is 44 years old and married with two children. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nairas to purchase more merchandise. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry supplies to sell

loans.name: Ehtibar

texts.en: Ehtibar

loans.use: To purchase more dishes

loans.name: Afde No 20 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 20 ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de poissons et légumes.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de poissons et légumes qu’elles vont vendre en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Les poissons font partie essentiel de la cuisine sénégalaise, donc il y a toujours beaucoup de demande.
