Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 20 000CFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 20” is composed of five women who average 45 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal. These women know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling fish and vegetables. They are very experienced and in high demand in this business.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC, and they indeed repaid it.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of fish and vegetables, which they will sell retail in cash transactions at the Grand Thiès marketplace. Fish is an essential part of Senegalese cuisine, so there is always a lot of demand.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 20,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and vegetables

loans.name: Sakinaxanım

texts.en:
Sakinaxanım K., 55 years old and single, has been a teacher for her whole life. It is very hard to make a living on a teacher's salary alone and eight years ago she found that sewing can bring in a good income.

Sakinaxanım went to a special sewing and modeling school and successfully completed her courses. Now Sakinaxanım is a very popular seamstress in Sabirabad city. She not only makes the garments but also designs suits, dresses and other items for women.

Sakinaxanım enjoys her job and would like to open her own studio. She needs to purchase a modern sewing machine to speed up the whole sewing process since her orders are increasing every day. She has applied for a $1500 US loan. Let's do our best to help this brave and hardworking woman.

loans.use: To purchase a modern sewing machine

loans.name: Zeynal

texts.en:
Zeynal A.'s main source of income is his calves which he fattens and sells to the local bazaar traders. He also has a job as department chief in the local post office. Zeynal has been involved in livestock breeding since an early age when he had no other job and his family needed the money. He is 39 years old and lives with his wife and 3 children in Sabirabad city. 

Zeynal has applied for a loan to purchase more calves and enlarge his business. He is the only breadwinner in his family and he believes that it is very important to provide his children with an excellent education. We believe in Zeynal's clear vision for the future.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Saleh

texts.en: Saleh N. is a trader who has run his own business selling spare parts in Sabirabad city for the last six years. He started this business with his savings and money borrowed from his friends. Now he has paid off all his debts and purchased his own shop. Saleh is married and has three children. He has applied for $2000 US to purchase more spare parts for foreign cars which have become very popular with people in the last 2 years.

loans.use: To purchase new spare parts for foreign cars

loans.name: Marachi B Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Salima, age 51, is widowed with 5 kids aged 20, 17, 15, 13, and 8 years and two dependents, all in school. She has been a tailor since 2007 located at the customs Busia border. She struggles to overcome her challenges. She is requesting this loan to purchase materials for clothing hoping to add more capital to her business for a change. Her community benefits from her skills. Her dream is to buy land, construct a house and make a good home.

loans.use: To purchase materials for clothing

loans.name: Sarmes

texts.en: Sarmes T. is a 45-year-old farmer who has been living in the Internally Displaced People Settlement with his two sons since 1991. He and his family suffered from Azerbaijan-Armenian conflict. He started livestock breeding in 1995 when poverty pushed him to find a source of income to cover his family's basic needs. Owing to the loan from AqroInvest, Sarmes could make his business successful. He regards himself as a trusted client and has now applied for his second loan from KIVA. He requests a loan of USD 1525 to purchase three calves for an estimated price USD 500 each. Let’s wish him good luck!

loans.use: to purchase three calves

loans.name: Mawero East B- Nabwire Sawuya Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Sawuya, 42, is married with four kids. Her first born is 20 years old while her last born is 6 years old. She also takes care of three orphans, all of whom attend school. She lives in Mawero East B in Busia where she has been selling cereals (maize, beans, soya, millet, sorghum) for over 20 years. She requests a loan of USD 1800 to purchase cereals.

loans.use: To purchase cereals (maize, beans, soya, millet, sorghum)

loans.name: Afde No 19 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 19 ont une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de poissons et la restauration.  Elles ont appris à cuisinier depuis elles étaient jeunes, donc elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de poissons et de renforcer son activité de restauration, au comptant au marché Grand Thiès.  Les poissons font partie essentiel de la cuisine sénégalaise, donc il y a toujours beaucoup de demande.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000CFA ($60) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 19” is composed of five women who average 50 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Grand Thiès district in the city of Thiès, located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal. These women know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, fish selling and food catering. They learned how to cook when they were young, so they are very experienced and in high demand in this business.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC that they indeed repaid.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of fish and to bolster their restaurant business, accepting cash at the Grand Thiès marketplace. Fish is an essential part of Senegalese cuisine, so there is always a lot of demand.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and to strengthen their catering business

loans.name: Emin

texts.en: Emin R. is a 31-year-old farmer who breeds and sells calves in the local livestock bazaar. He is married with two children. He started his business in 2004 when his salary as a policeman was not enough to cover his family’s basic needs. Now he has a successful business, but his income is not sufficient to achieve his main goal - provide best education to his beloved children. He dreams of owning a livestock farm in the future. He is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more calves, which is the first step towards achieving his dream.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia L. is a 40-year-old mother of seven. Her husband Richard is a fisherman and carpenter. Two of her children are going to enroll in college, four are in elementary school and one is still young and needs to be fed.  The family resides in a beautiful village along the sea, where fishing is the common livelihood of the people. 

 Cecilia joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital. She applied for this loan to purchase a motor for their fishing boat. She wants her husband to be able to fish in a deeper part of the sea in order to have a good catch to sell volumes of fish for her savings. She has hopes of sending her children to a university, and of having a beautiful house for them to live in.

loans.use: To buy a motor  for their pump boat

loans.name: Bayandik

texts.en:
Bayandik T. is a 40-year-old farmer. He is married and has two adorable daughters.

He has seven years of experience breeding calves. He purchase small calves, fattens them, and then, after several months, sells them to the local traders. He wakes up early in the morning to pasture them in the field. All day long, he spends with his calves. Calf breeding is the only source of income for Bayandik`s family and he tries very hard to meet the family's needs.

Bayandik has applied for a loan of $1200 USD to purchase two calves and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase two calves

loans.name: Mawero East B Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Shamimu is 35 years old. She is married and has four children, three of whom are in school. She also cares for three orphans. She has been selling women's clothing -- skirts, blouses, and dresses -- for over 7 years. She is using this loan to buy more clothes. She is hard-working and dreams of building a house and rearing poultry and livestock.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes (skirts, blouse, dresses mostly ladies)

loans.name: Rena

texts.en:
Rena A. is a 38-year-old woman who has dedicated her life to her three sons. Rena`s main business is livestock breeding. After finishing school, she got married and did not have any chance to work or study because, all her life, she was looking after children. But in 1996 when her husband lost his job, she offered to start their own business.

With a loan from AqroInvest, Rena and her family started breeding livestock. Now that Rena's son is entering the university, she needs more income to pay for his education. For this purpose, Rena has applied for $1200 USD loan to purchase two calves and increase her income. Rena has a good client history and, with your help and generosity, we would be proud to support this hardworking woman.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Makhammad

texts.en: Makhammad N. is a 54-year-old trader who lives and works in the small village of Imishli. He is married and has two children. He has been selling different kinds of food, such as candies, coolies (a shaved ice treat), macaroni, and sugar, since 2002. He is not alone in his business. His wife and children also help him while he works as a driver using his car and taking local people to the downtown. He is the only breadwinner and his store is the family's only source of income. Makhammad has applied for $2000 USD to increase his stock.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Marachi B Group

texts.en: Mrs. Nanyasi Magret is 25 years old. She has three children, two of whom are in school, and she also cares for three orphans. She is using this loan to purchase more used clothes. She has been selling clothes for over 5 years. She encourages the community to wake up and work. She is courageous and she is determined to buy a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Agasemed

texts.en:
Agasemed S. is av 33-year-old trader who sells phone accessories in the small village of Imishli. He started his business 10 years ago when he got married. When he first started this business, he was renting the store, but now he owns his store, which he purchased two years ago.

Agasemed is married and has two children. He is trying to improve his business so that he can provide the best possible education and life conditions for his children.

Agasemed is applying for a $3000 USD loan to purchase phones and start selling them in his store. This business has become is very profitable in the last two years and phones are in high demand among local people. We wish him all the best!

loans.use: To purchase phones for sale

loans.name: Sophia A Group

texts.en: Mrs. M. Sumaya is 28 years old. She is a widow. She has four children, all of whom go to school, and she also cares for two orphans. She has been selling used clothes for over 3 years. She is using the loan to purchase more used clothing. Mrs. M. Sumaya is looking forward to a change in her business and her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes to sell .

loans.name: Amavi Ognimélé

texts.fr: Madame O. amavi ognimélé est une veuve qui habite avec ses 02 enfants le quartier  d’agbalépédo qui est un quartier de la ville de Lomé. L’activité qu’elle exerce pour subvenir aux charges de ses enfants est la vente de charbons de bois. Elle exerce son commerce dans son quartier de résidence en gros et en détail, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1990. Elle a besoin de rehausser son stock pour cela elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20  sacs de charbons de bois et assurer les frais de transport.
texts.en:
Ms. O. Amavi Ognimélé is a widow who lives with her two children in Agbalépédo, a district in the city of Lomé. To provide for her children, she works selling charcoal. She does commerce wholesale and retail in the district where she lives and has been working at it since 1990. She needs to replenish her stock. To do so, she’s requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 20 sacks of charcoal and to cover transportation costs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Arubaine C Group

texts.en: Mrs. H. Talibu is 21 years old. She is married and has two children, ages 6 and 1. She is using the loan to purchase new and used clothes, specifically ladies' and children's clothes. She has been able to pay school fees for her child. She is happy and hardworking and her dream is to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase new and used clothes, specifically ladies' and children's clothing

loans.name: Parvana

texts.en:
"Hi, dear lenders. Thank you very much for the loan. As you know, I applied for the loan from you two years ago. I improved my business with your help and support. I am very happy that Kiva raised the loan amount to $3000."

Parvana is applying for the second loan from Kiva. She applied for the first loan in 2007. She repaid this loan successfully.

This young woman would like to improve her cattle-breeding business. Now she needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy five calves.

loans.use: To buy 5 calves

loans.name: Afde No 15 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 15 ont une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Certaines d’entre elles exercent l’activité de restauration, et certaines vendent de tissus.  Elles ont appris à cuisinier depuis elles étaient jeunes, donc elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Les habits des femmes en Afrique de L’Ouest font un parti de la culture essentiel, et toutes les femmes port les vêtements très colorants, donc le commerce de tissus marche bien.  Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de tissus et de renforcer son activité de restauration, au comptant au marché Grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30 000CFA ($60) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE Numéro 15” is composed of five women who average 38 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Grand Thiès district in the city of Thiès, located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. They know one another through ties of community and kinship. Some of them do food catering, and some sell cloth. They learned how to cook when they were young, so they are very experience and in high demand in these businesses. Women’s clothing in West Africa is an essential part of the culture, and all women wear very colorful clothing. Commerce in fabrics therefore does well.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC, and they indeed repaid it.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of cloth and to bolster their restaurant business, accepting cash at the Grand Thiès marketplace.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and to strengthen their restaurant business

loans.name: Arubaine C Group

texts.en: Mrs. Robina M. is 40 years old. She is married and has 13 children who all go to school. She has been in business for four years. She is using the loan to purchase dry fish. Being active and hard working, she now buys in large quantities and she wants to fulfill her goals of educating her children and buying a plot of land.

loans.use: Purchases dry fish in large quantities

loans.name: Georgette

texts.fr: Madame Georgette ANAYADRI a pour activité la vente de pagnes, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2006 à Nukafu, son point d’approvisionnement est le grand marché de lomé. Elle veut agrandir son stock raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier cycle de prêt qui lui permettrai d’acheter des pièces de pagnes de haute qualité. Elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est  un conducteur de Taxi, avec le revenu qu’elle gagne de son commerce elle aide son mari dans les charges quotidiennes du foyer.
texts.en:
Ms. Georgette ANAYADRI works in the business of selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth). She has been in this business since 2006 in Nukafu. The grand marketplace of Lomé is where she acquires her supplies. She wants to expand her inventory, which is why she’s requesting her first loan from WAGES. This loan will enable her to buy bolts of high quality pagnes. She is married to a gentleman who is a taxi driver. With the revenues she earns from her commerce, she helps her husband with day-to-day household expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagne cloth

loans.name: Mayombe Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Annet, age 28, has been in business for over 10 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase items for her retail shop: specifically maize flour, wheat flour, millet flour, rice, beans, cooking oil, sugar, soap, tea leaves, etc. She is married with 5 kids age 8, 6, 3, 2, and 1 years old. She has been living up to her challenges and can now purchase stock in large quantities. Mrs. Annet is an active woman taking care of her home and paying her kids' school fees.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for shop

loans.name: Mayombe Group

texts.en: Mrs. N. Grace, 38 years old, married with 4 kids in school, has been a tailor for over 10 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase material  for gomas, bitegi, skirts and blouses, dresses, etc. She has managed to feed the family and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase cloth

loans.name: Solof Group

texts.en: Mrs. M. Zam is 33 years old, married with 7 children and 2 orphans, all going to school. Mrs. M. Zam has been selling clothes that are gomases (traditional wear) for over 8 years now. She will use this loan to buy gomases. The added capital will make her business boom. She is proud that she can take care of her family and pay her kids' school fees. She is determined to construct a residential house and tenant houses for rent.

loans.use: To buy gomases (traditional wear)

loans.name: Afde No 16 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 16 ont une moyenne d’âge de 48 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy de Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de cola, légumes, et huile de palme. Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de marchandises qui sont vendues en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25,000 CFA ($50) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE Numéro 16” is composed of five women who average 48 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. These women know one another through ties of community and kinship. They do almost the same work, selling cola, vegetables, and palm oil. They are very experienced and in high demand in these fields.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC, and they indeed repaid it.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of merchandise, which will be sold retail, cash accepted, at the Grand Thiès marketplace.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Nabulola Group

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Agnes Madina is 30 years old. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school. She also cares for another school-aged child.

Mrs. M. Agnes is using this loan to buy and sell new clothes (jeans, skirts, suits, and blouses). She has been in this business for over six years. She is hard-working and active, and she feels good because she can solve her problems and her life is an example to her community. Her dream is to succeed in her business.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell

loans.name: Solof Group

texts.en: Mrs. E. Betty is 25 years old and married. She has a five-year-old child who is in school. She has a hair-dressing salon for plaiting, treating, retouching, and styling hair. She has had her salon for four years. The major challenge with her business is that when the electricity is off, she cannot serve her customers. She is using this loan to purchase a generator, and a hair drier and hair rollers to improve her business. Her dream is to buy a plot of land and have a good home.

loans.use: Purchase equipment (generator, drier, hair rollers)

loans.name: Tororo Road Group

texts.en: Ms. Namagila Madina is a 28-year-old single woman. She has three children and also cares for four other children. All of the children are in school. She is using this loan to purchase shoes for ladies, kids, and gents. She is hardworking and innovative, and she has been selling shoes for over 5 years. She wants to help people in her community, construct a house, and educate her children.

loans.use: Purchases shoes for ladies, kids, and gents

loans.name: Afde 18 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 18 ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Cité Lamy à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de poissons qu’elles vont vendre en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Les poissons font partie essentiel de la cuisine sénégalaise, donc il y a toujours beaucoup de demande.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30,000 CFA ($60) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
“Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE Numéro 18” is composed of five women who average 40 years of age and who live in large traditional extended families in the Cité Lamy district in Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. These women know one another through ties of community and kinship. They do almost the same work, selling fish. They are very experienced and in high demand in this field.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They received a group loan before from IMCEC, and they indeed repaid it.

The group members plan to use this loan to replenish their stock of fish, which they’re going to sell retail, cash accepted, at the Grand Thiès marketplace. Fish is an essential part of Senegalese cuisine, so there is always a lot of demand.

The group members hope to realize an average profit of 30,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for family needs, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Marachi B Group

texts.en: Mrs. Z. Mariam is married, and is 40 years old. She has six children, all of whom are in school, and she also cares for two other children. She is using this loan to purchase bags of charcoal. She has been selling charcoal for over 20 years. She wants to educate her children and encourage others in her community to work. She is active and her goals are to develop herself and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita A. is blessed to send all her children to college and have their own family. The couple worked together to grow their business. Rebecca joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital to support her store. She is applying for a loan to buy assorted feed varieties to retail. 

Aside from the purpose of earning an income, she wants to serve her neighbors in the village in order for them not to have to go  to the town proper anymore just to buy a kilo of feed. She hopes that in the future, she can have a stall in the market and save for their old age.

loans.use: To buy assorted feed varieties to retail

loans.name: Marygine

texts.en:
Marygine is a mother of four and is married to Corat. She has a business buying vegetables from farmers and selling the vegetables in the local market in Belo, her village. With this loan, Marygine plans to purchase eight buckets of potatoes, ten buckets of cocoyams and 18 buckets of beans, including three buckets of koki beans.

With the gradual repayment schedule and the ability to set aside some of her profits, Marygine is confident her business will continue to succeed.  With this loan, Marygine believes that her business will help her community because she is providing more food to choose from at a convenient location.  

As her business profits from the loan, Marygine will be able to expand her business, buy food and needed items for her family, and most importantly, pay for her children's school fees.  Out of her four children, three of them are under the age of fifteen.  The ability to pay for these costs helps Marygine and her family, especially since they have faced some of life's challenges, like deep poverty.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy potatoes, cocoyams, beans, and koki beans

loans.name: Salomé

texts.fr:
G. Salomé est née le 01/06/1959 à Djougou au Nord Ouest du Bénin. Salomé est mariée à BASSAN Louis, elle a cinq (5) enfants avec son mari, tous scolarisés. seuls trois (3)enfants restent encore à la charge de Salomé et son mari. Salomé est dactylographe de formation. Salomé a exercé la dactylographie jusqu'en 1994 où elle fut sortie de la fonction publique. C'est alors que Salomé s'est mise à faire de petit commerce. Salomé achète et revend les fournitures scolaires. Puis Salomé a diversifié son activité à la vente des articles de mercerie (boutons, fils à coudre, popelines, etc.). Salomé a déjà eu deux prêts de ALIDé. Salomé sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
G. Salomé was born on June 1, 1959 in Djougou in northwest Benin. She is married to BASSAN Louis, and with her husband, she has five children, all schooled. Only three children are still supported by her and her husband. Salomé is a typist by training and worked at it until 1994, when she left the public sector. This is why she got started in small-scale commerce. She bought and resold school supplies. Then she diversified her business by selling sewing supplies (buttons, thread, popelines, etc.) Salomé has already had two Alidé loans before and is requesting a third loan in order to bolster her business, so as to satisfy her customers better.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for micro-loan recipients.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy packets of thread, rolls of popeline, boxes of notebooks, and boxes of pens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing the necessary materials for his work

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn N. is thirty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to three children who are in the junior high and the basic schools. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Aquase, a fishing community near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Evelyn says that it is important for her to work hard to make some income to support her husband and take care of the family. She is a trader. She sells grocers, such as milk, sugar, candies, bread, etc. She buys the goods from wholesale dealers in Cape Coast, the regional capital, and sells them in her community. She owns a shop by the roadside in which she sells. Evelyn also supplies firewood to local food vendors.

She has been in business for barely one year and wants a loan to buy more goods to stock her shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Muneratu

texts.en:
Muneratu M. is thirty-seven years old. She is a married mother of five children who are all currently in school. One of them is in the senior high school. The rest are in the junior high and the primary school. Muneratu lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Aquase, a fishing community near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

She is a trader. She prepares and sells palm oil. Palm oil is prepared from the palm nuts. The cooked palm is pounded, mixed with hot water, sieved and boiled for several hours. The reddish substance, which is the oil, is skimmed off and boiled again to expel water content.

She buys the palm nuts from farmers in the nearby communities. She distributes the oil to retailers and food vendors. Muneratu has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy palm nuts in bulk. She hopes to improve her standard of living and give her children the best of education that she can afford.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Afde N°4 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°4  ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Mbambara Aly LO (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de Jumbo, crème glace, poissons secs et poissons fumés. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de Jumbo, crème glace, poissons secs et poissons fumés. Les Jumbo, crème glace, poissons secs et poissons fumés sont vendus en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the "Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°4" group have an average age of 40 and live in big extended traditional families in the Mbambara Aly LO district (Thiès region). They met because of living in the same neighborhood or being related to each other. They have almost the same businesses selling Jumbo (bouillon cubes), ice cream, dried fish and smoked fish. They are much sought after in these activities.

In the desire to improve the quality of their services and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the trust group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC, with whom they are on their second solidarity loan. Their first loan was correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to stock up on Jumbo bouillon cubes, ice cream, and dried and smoked fish. These items are sold retail, for cash, in the big market of Thiès. They each hope to make an average profit of 25,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover the needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: building up their inventory

loans.name: Françoise

texts.fr:
P. Françoise est née le 02/03/1956 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Françoise est mariée à KPATINKPO Eusèbe, un retraité des Chemins de fer. Françoise a cinq (5) enfants tous scolarisés. Françoise est couturière de formation; mais elle n'a exercé ce métier que jusqu'en 1979. Actuellement,
Françoise achète et revend des tissus au grand marché international de Bénin. Françoise vend aussi divers articles de grande consommation: bombons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, etc. Françoise a eu déjà deux crédits de ALIDé, grâce auxquels elle a pu apporter un changement qualitatif et quantitatif dans son activité. Françoise a pour projet d'augmenter le niveau de son commerce. Françoise compte aussi diversifier son activité à la vente de charbon de bois. C'est pour toutes ces raisons que Françoise sollicite un troisième crédit à ALIDé.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Françoise P. was born on March 2, 1956 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Françoise is married to Eusèbe Kpatinkpo, who is retired from railroad work. Françoise has 5 children, all in school. She is a trained seamstress but she only practiced that trade until 1979. <> Presently, Françoise buys and sells cloth in the big international market of Bénin. Françoise also sells staples such as candy, sweet biscuits, tins of milk, sardines, and tomatoes; sugar, pasta, detergents and dish detergents, toilet soap, etc. Françoise has already received two loans from ALIDé, thanks to which she was able to change her little business in qualitative and quantitative ways. Her goal is to raise the level of her business. She also intends to diversify her business by selling charcoal. For all these reasons, Françoise is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language, Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of US$ 1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for micro-loan recipients.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing sacks of maize, sacks of charcoal, and sacks of rice

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana O. is fifty-two years old. She is a married mother of three children who are all currently in school. One of the three children has just completed the senior high school and plans to continue. The rest are in the junior high and the primary schools. Diana lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Diana runs a restaurant. She sells all kinds of local dishes, such as fufu and banku, and other continental dishes. Banku is prepared from corn dough and the fufu is a pounded and cooked cassava with plantains. Both meals are served hot with soup.

Diana says that she buys the raw materials, such as maize, cassava, plantain, fish, and other vegetables, from the local market. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy raw materials in bulk. She hopes to improve her standard of living and give her children the best of education that she can afford.

loans.use: To buy food for her restaurant

loans.name: Berlie

texts.en:
Berlie B. is a 50-year-old mother of seven. Her husband Lolito is a carpenter.  She worked very hard to raise her big family. She sells fish and makes food for snacks to support the needs of her children. She applied for this loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle to be used in fish vending for her husband to sell even in far-off villages. 

She hopes to save money to increase her capital for fish vending. She dreams of sending her children to college and landing a better job.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorcycle for fish vending

loans.name: Andrews

texts.en:
Andrews A. is sixty-three years old. He is married and has five children. Two of the children are currently in school. The rest are out of school and living independently. He lives with some of his children and his wife in a family house in Aquase, a fishing community near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Andrew is a trader. He sells all kinds of footwear for men. He sells full shoes, half shoes, slippers, etc. He buys the goods from wholesalers in the regional capital. Andrews sells his products on a table top in the market square. He says he also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Andrews has been in business for twenty years and wants a loan to buy footwear in bulk so that he can increase his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy footwear to resell

loans.name: Alimatou

texts.fr: Alimatou T. est une veuve de 45ans avec 4 enfants en charge. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son capital et promouvoir son activité de vente de tissu teint à l’indigo « Thioup ». Elle fait en même temps un petit commerce de crème et de glace, très rentable en cette période de chaleur.
texts.en:
Alimatou T. is a widow of 45, raising 4 children. She is requesting this loan to bolster her working capital and expand her little business selling indigo dyed cloth called "Thioup". She also sells ice cream, which is quite lucrative in this hot weather.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase and re-sale of dyed cloth and ice cream

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice S. is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, two of whom are currently in school; one in senior high and the other in junior high schools. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in Aquase, a fishing community near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Beatrice is a trader. She trades in second-hand textiles, including clothing for both men and women. She also sells bedsheets and other textile materials. She says she hawks (sells door-to-door) to sell her goods and treks to other markets to sell. Beatrice also sometimes sells at the market square in her community. Beatrice buys bales of textiles from wholesalers in the nearby towns.

She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy bales of textiles in bulk to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia S. is forty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to four children. According to her, two of them are currently in school, one in high school and one in junior high. The other two have completed high school and have been working for a while. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase near the Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. Cecilia is a trader. She trades in second-hand textiles. She sells dresses for women. She also sells bed sheets and other textile materials. Cecilia says she hawks to sell her goods and treks to other markets to sell. She also sells sometimes at the local market square. She procures bales of textiles from wholesalers in the nearby towns. Cecilia has been in business for fourteen years and wants a loan to procure bales of textiles in bulk to increase her profit margin. She desires to give her children the best education.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes and textiles in bulk.

loans.name: Adeshola

texts.en: Adeshola is 43 years old and married with four children. She sells chewing sticks to her customers. The demand for chewing sticks is high, and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of $350 to purchase more chewing sticks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chewing sticks to sell

loans.name: Afde N°6 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°6  ont une moyenne d’âge de35 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiès (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de pomme de terre, divers et aussi la restauration. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important. Le restaurant   et les pommes de terre sont vendus au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the "Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°6" group have an average age of 35 and live in big extended traditional families in the Grand Thies neighborhood (Thiès region). They met because of living in the same neighborhood or being related to each other. They have almost the same businesses selling potatoes, various items, and cooked food. They are much sought after in these activities.

In the desire to improve the quality of their services and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the trust group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC, with whom they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). Their first loan was correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to increase their inventory. The cooked food and potatoes are sold for cash, in the market of Grand Thiès. They each hope to make an average profit of 30,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover the needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: enlarge their restaurant

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is 32 years old and she is married with 3 children. She sells clothes in retail to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of N50000 to purchase more clothes to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella sells foodstuffs and she loves this business because she has lots of customers. She is 29 years old and is married with 3 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca S. is forty years old. She is a married mother of one child, a son who is currently in the police service. She lives with her child and husband in a family house in a fishing community called Aquase near the Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.
Rebecca is a seamstress by profession. She owns a workshop at the market square. She says she sews all styles of ladies’ dresses for sale and also sews for clients who come to place an order with their own materials. She procures the fabrics from fashion shops in the big cities. Rebecca says she has apprentices who are in training. Meanwhile, a number of them have also graduated and are running their own businesses. She has been in this business for eight years. She wants a loan to procure sewing accessories and fabrics in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To procure fabrics in bulk and sewing accessories

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S. est une femme mariée âgée de 36 ans, mère de 02 enfants. Elle souhaite renforcer son capital de vente d’encens et de pate d’arachide. C’est avec cette activité qu’elle parvient à participer à la dépense quotidienne familiale.
texts.en:
Fatou S., 36, is a married woman and the mother of 2 children. She hopes to bolster her working capital for selling incense and peanut butter. It is thanks to this business that she manages to contribute to supporting her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: making and selling incense and peanut butter

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet B. is 54 years old. She is a married mother of six children. She says three children are working while three are still in school, in senior and junior high. Janet lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Janet is a trader. She trades in fashion accessories such as unisex belts, ladies’ bags and other leather products. She buys the products directly from the producers in the regional capital. She says she treks to towns to sell and also hawks in her community.

Janet has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to procure more goods. She hopes to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy fashion accessories for sale.

loans.name: Pélagie

texts.fr:
H. Pélagie est née vers 1985 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Pélagie a deux (2) enfants:  l'aîné est scolarisé, le benjamin est un nourrisson. Pélagie vend de poissons depuis cinq (5) ans. Pélagie achète de poissons frais chez son mari et d'autres pêcheurs au bord de la lagune de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin; qu'elle revend au grand marché international du Bénin. Pélagie a eu déjà deux crédits de ALIDé qui lui ont permis d'améliorer son niveau de vie. Aujourd'hui, Pélagie a pour projet d'augmenter le niveau de son commerce et d'aider son mari à acheter une nouvelle barque motorisée pour la pêche. C'est pourquoi Pélagie sollicite un troisième prêt auprès de ALIDé. 


 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Pélagie H. was born around 1985 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Pélagie has two children; the elder is in school, and the younger is still breast-feeding. Pélagie has been selling fish for 5 years. She buys fresh fish from her husband and other fishermen along the lagune of Cotonou, then sells them at the big international market of Bénin.

Pélagie has already had two loans from ALIDé and they have allowed her to improve her standard of living. Today, Pélagie's goal is to improve the level of her business and help her husband to buy a new motorboat for fishing. This is why Pélagie is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

The significance of AIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Bénin is a small West African country next door to Nigera; its GDP stands at US$ 1,500 per inhabitant. ALIDé offers special loans at 0% interest for very vulnerable people and it is among a group that are soon planning to offer a program of micro health insurance for micro-loan beneficiaries.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 15 baskets of fresh fish

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity sells drinks, foodstuffs and general provisions. Charity is 45 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a teacher.

Charity needs a loan of 70,000 NGN ($475) to buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy drinks, foodstuffs  and provisions for sale.

loans.name: Afde No 17 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 17 ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans et vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de denrées alimentaires.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans cette activité. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock de denrées alimentaires qu’elles vont vendre en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40,000 CFA ($80) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the "Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°17" group have an average age of 45 and live in big extended traditional families in the Grand Thiès district, a town 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. They met because of living in the same neighborhood or being related to each other. They have almost the same businesses selling foodstuffs. They are very experienced and much sought after in this activity.

In the desire to improve the quality of their services and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the trust group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They have already received one group loan from IMCEC and have correctly reimbursed it.

They intend to use this loan to stock up on foodstuffs which they will sell retail, for cash, in the market of Grand Thiès. They hope to make an average profit of 40,000 F CFA (US$ 80) during this loan cycle, which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover the needs of their families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: Afde N°7 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°7  ont une moyenne d’âge de35 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Som (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de poissons secs et fumés, d’huile de palme et des tissus. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important. Les produits sont vendus au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The 5 women of the "Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N° 7" group have an average age of 35 and live in big extended traditional families in the Som district (Thies region). They met because of living in the same neighborhood or being related to each other. They have almost the same businesses selling smoked and dried fish, palm oil, and cloth. They are much sought after in these activities.

In the desire to improve the quality of their services and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the trust group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC, with whom they are on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan was correctly reimbursed.

They intend to use this loan to stock up. Their products are sold for cash, in the market of Grand Thiès. They each hope to make an average profit of 25,000 F CFA during this loan cycle, which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover the needs of their extended families, investing any remainder back into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expanding their business inventory

loans.name: Isoken

texts.en:
Isoken I. sells kerosene. She is a 65-year-old widow with 6 children.

She needs a loan of 120,000 NGN (825 USD) to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Hagar

texts.en:
Hagar K. is 37 and married with four children who are still in school. Some are in junior high and others in the basic school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Hagar says it is necessary for her to work to make some income to help her husband to support the family. Though a hairdresser by profession, Hagar trades in provisions as well.

She buys provisions such as milk, sugar, candies, bread, etc. from wholesale dealers in the regional capital, Cape Coast, and sells on a table top in front of her salon. Hagar also sells fresh fish and chicken.

She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure more goods to stock her shop.

loans.use: To buy provisions for sale.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: La jeune dame Fatoumata Soumaré est agée de 29 ans, mariée et a en charge 06 enfants. Elle s’active dans la vente de tissu teint « Thioup » et souhaite renforcer son capital. Elle compte ainsi subvenir aux besoins de sa famille en nourriture et santé.
texts.en:
Fatoumata Soumaré is a young lady, aged 29, married and responsible for 6 children. She sells dyed cloth called "Thioup" and would like to bolster her working capital. In this way, she expects to be be able to help cover her family's needs in food and health concerns.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase and resale of dyed cloth

loans.name: Tawa

texts.en: Tawa M. is 42 years old and married with 7 children. She has a grinding machine that she uses to grind foodstuffs like corn, beans, pepper etc. She needs a loan  of 100,000 NGN (700 USD) to purchase another grinding machine to enable her meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy a grinding machine

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is a sixty-two-year-old widow with five children. She says all her children are grown ups and living independently. She lives with some grandchildren in a family house in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Mary is a trader. She trades in plastic products such bowls, cups, buckets, etc. She buys the goods from wholesalers in the nearby towns. Mary treks to other towns to sell her products on their market days. She says she also sells at the market square in her community. Mary also trades in other products such as scrubbing brushes, calendars, etc. She has been in this business for 40 years and wants a loan to buy the goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy plastic products for sale.

loans.name: Mame Sophie

texts.fr: Mame Sophie C. est une femme mariée de 53 ans qui a en charge 05 neveux et nièces. Elle s’active dans la vente de crème et de glace, bon marché en cette période de chaleur. Cette activité qu’elle mène, en plus de la vente de tissus teint « Thioup » qu’elle fait aussi, lui permet de nourrir les enfants dont elle a la charge.
texts.en:
Mame Sophie C. is 53, married, and has five nephews and nieces to support. She is active in selling cream and ice-cream, a good activity in this period of heat. This business she handles together with the sale of dyed "thioup" cloth, allows her to meet the food needs of her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To produce and sell cream and ice

loans.name: Afde N°8 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°8  ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Randouléne Sud (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente des tissus et mercerie. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de tissus et mercerie. Les tissus et mercerie sont vendus au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
"Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°8" is a group composed of five women who average 45 years of age living in large traditional extended families in the Randouléne Sud district (region of Thiès). The women know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling cloth and sewing supplies. They are in high demand in these field.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC and are now on their second solidarity loan (group loan). Their first loan was correctly repaid.

With this loan, the group members plan to build a sizable stock of cloth and sewing supplies, which will be sold, cash accepted, at the grand marketplace of Thiès.

Each group member hopes to realize an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and sewing supplies

loans.name: Magnus

texts.en:
Magnus N. is 35 years old. He is married with three children. He says two of them are in junior high school and one is in senior high. He lives with his children and wife in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Magnus is a trader. He trades in all kinds of hardware (building materials) such as bags of cement, iron rods, roofing sheets, nails, etc. He buys the goods from wholesalers in the regional capital. Magnus owns a shop in which he sells his products. He has been in business for 12 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy materials for sale in his hardware shop.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa H. is 35 years old and is a single mother of one child. Her child is in school at the community where they live. Adwoa lives at Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana with her family.

She trades in fish to earn a living. Adwoa buys her stock at the seashore directly from the fishermen, because at that place the fish are cheap. She buys what she can afford which is not much. She fries the fish and arranges them in a sieve. She mostly sells through hawking as she does not have money to rent a store in the market. She has customers whom she supplies with quality fish.

It is her dream to buy more fish so that she can better manage her trade. Her customers place their order for fish and Adwoa will take her time to smoke some of the fish for them, apart from the frying. This has helped her to maintain a strong customer base.

Her major problem has to do with adequate funds to expand her stock. She is therefore requesting a loan to enable her to buy more fish. Adwoa means ‘Monday born’ . She says your support is much needed. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame Bekyere’ which means God will provide.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, fresh fish etc. for her fish-selling business.

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr:
M. Albertine est née le 14/07/1950 à Abomey dans le Département du Zou au Centre du Bénin. Albertine a cinq enfants tous scolarisés. Albertine est couturière de formation; mais elle a abandonné la couture depuis vingt (20) ans au profit de la distribution-vente de divers articles: tissus, ustensiles de cuisines, etc. Actuellement, Albertine fait de la production animale notamment l'élevage de lapins. Pour développer son élevage de lapins et diversifier ses activités à la vente de friperie, Albertine sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé.


  
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
M. Albertine was born on July 14, 1950 in Abomey in Zou County in central Benin. She has five children, all schooled, and is a seamstress by training; but she abandoned this trade twenty years ago in favor of the distribution-sales of various goods: cloth, kitchen utensils, etc. Currently, she works in animal production, notably raising rabbits. To develop her rabbit farm and to diversify her business with the sale of second-hand clothing, she's requesting a loan from ALIDÉ.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a bale of used clothing, sacks of rabbit feed, bottles of rabbit medicine

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is a dealer and seller of underwear and children’s wear, as well as shirts, blouses, pampers and sanitary pads. She has a passion for what she does because she says it brings her more satisfaction when she sells. Due to the nature of her work she hawks through her surrounding communities to sell her goods.

Ama A. is 32 years old and is married with three children who are in school. She has been selling through hawking for seven years now. She is not interested in renting a store because she says her goods would not sell fast when she is in a store. She is hard working, strong and has a strong passion for what she does.

Her major concern is having enough cash. Therefore Ama is requesting your help to buy more products to increase her inventory. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Otease’ which means ‘He lives’. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy underwear and children's wear, shirts and blouses.

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda S. is 38 years old. She is married with three children, one in senior high, one in junior high and the youngest in primary school. Matilda lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana.

Matilda is a hard-working woman. She is a trader in cosmetics. She buys cosmetics such as body sprays, powder, creams, etc. and sells them on a table top in the community market. Matilda also treks to other markets to sell on their market days.

She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy varieties of cosmetics in bulk. Matilda hopes to give her children the best education she can afford and to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics to sell at the markets.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariame D. est une dame de 57 ans, veuve et mère de 03 enfants dont elle a la charge.  Elle achète des graines d’arachide afin d’en faire de la pâte pour la vendre. Elle souhaite avec ce prêt promouvoir son activité qui lui permet d’assurer la nourriture à sa famille
texts.en:
Mariame D. is a 57-year-old woman, a widow, and a mother of three children, who are in her care. She buys peanuts to make peanut butter from them to be sold. She would like to use this loan to promote her business, which enables her to ensure food for her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To process and sell peanut butter

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity O. is 28 years old, married and the mother of four children. Through the help of government free compulsory education, it has been possible for her to send all her kids to school. She lives at Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. Charity trades in peas, pineapple and tiger nuts and sells through hawking. It is believed that tiger nuts can help those with sexual weakness. She travels to the surrounding communities to buy her stock of goods. Demand for her goods is on the higher side; for that reason she is requesting a loan to buy more peas, pineapple and tiger nuts. Charity wants to save more money for her children's education. She belongs to a village bank called ‘He lives’.

loans.use: To buy peas, tiger nuts, pineapple and others.

loans.name: Afde N°9 Group

texts.fr: Les cinq femmes du groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°9 ont une moyenne d’âge de 45 ans vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiés (région de Thiès). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente des tissus et chaussures. Elles sont très sollicitées dans ces activités. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de micro finance IMCEC avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).  Leur premier prêt était  correctement remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour constituer un stock important de tissus et chaussures. Les tissus et chaussures sont vendus au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
"Association Femme Développement Entreprise AFDE N°9" is a group composed of five women who average 45 years of age living in large traditional extended families in the Grand Thiés district (region of Thiès). The women know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling cloth and shoes. They are in high demand in these fields.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC and are now on their second solidarity loan (group loan). Their first loan was correctly repaid.

With this loan, the group members plan to build a sizable stock of cloth and shoes, which will be sold, cash accepted, at the grand marketplace of Thiès.

Each group member hopes to realize an average profit of 35,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth and shoes

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa T. is 62 years old, married and the mother of ten children. All her children are fully independent and are working. She lives at Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana. Though Adwoa is old she is a very hardworking and lovely mother who encourages the youth to be serious in their God-given talents. She sells drinks in a wooden structured bar. She sells items like Coca Cola, Pepsi, Malta, Sprite, and any other assorted drink which is frequently demanded by her clients. Not long ago Adwoa started this business in order to take care of herself. She started this business and raised money by herself but has realized that it is not enough to buy more drinks. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy more assorted drinks to be able to provide for her sick husband. She would be grateful for your support. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Mpeasem’, which simply means I don’t want trouble.

loans.use: To buy assorted drinks like Coke, Pepsi, canned drinks etc.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa A. is 65 years old. She is married and has sons and daughters who are all grown up and live independently. She lives with her grandchildren and husband in a family house in a fishing community called Aquase, near Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. 
Adwoa is a trader. She trades in foodstuffs such as yam, plantain, cassava, etc. and other food items such as onions and eggs. She procures the goods from the farmers in the nearby small communities at effective prices. She treks to other towns to sell. Adwoa says food vendors and other retailers normally purchase from her. She has been in business for so many years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to be able to distribute to more customers.

loans.use: To procure foodstuffs and fruits

loans.name: Minsito

texts.fr: Mensito Traoré est mariée et mère de 04 enfants. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour promouvoir son activité de vente de crème et de glace qu’elle prépare elle-même. Ce petit commerce, en plus de la vente de tissu teinté « Thioup » lui permet de subvenir aux besoins en nourriture de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mensito Traoré is married and the mother of four. She's requesting this loan to promote her business selling cream and ice, which she makes herself. This little business, in addition to selling dyed "thioup" cloth, enables her to meet the food needs of her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell cream and ice

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua O. is 40 years old, married and the mother of four children. Currently three of her children are working and her last is still in senior high school. She lives at Eguase in the central region of Ghana. She is a trader who deals with assorted products like cooking utensils and plastic bowls, lunch boxes etc. She mostly sells through hawking, which is house-to-house selling. She has been trading for five years now. She has attracted lots of customers who purchase from her stand. She treks to Accra to purchase her stock of goods. Recently she has been facing challenges in her business as a result of inadequate funds to buy stock. She is requesting a loan to buy more products like cooking utensils etc., which are frequently demanded by her numerous customers. With the loan, she believes she will be more prepared to make lots of profit, to build a store, and to reduce the frequent walking in the street to sell. She would be grateful for your assistance. Akua belongs to a village bank called ‘Mpeasem’, which simply means I don’t want trouble.

loans.use: To increase her stock of inventory like cooking utensils.

loans.name: Masseye

texts.fr: Monsieur Masseye G. est un commerçant de pièces détachées qui habite au quartier Cité Lamy à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Avant, il était mécanicien, mais avec l’aide des fonds provenant d’une tontine, il a acheté des pièces détachées pour les revendre a la gare routière de Thiès.  Il sollicite son premier crédit auprès de l’IMCEC et Kiva pour renforcer son activité.  Monsieur G. est célibataire et avec les revenus de son entreprise il se soutient.
texts.en:
Mr. Masseye G. is a merchant of spare parts who lives in the Cité Lamy district of Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Sénégal. In the past, he was a mechanic, but with the help of funds from a tontine (a community revolving savings and loan group), he bought spare parts in order to resell them at the Thiès bus station. He's requesting his first loan from IMCEC and Kiva to bolster his business. Mr. G. is unmarried and, with the revenues from his enterprise, he supports himself.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce A. is 32 years old. She is single and seriously looking for her better half. Joyce is a physically challenged person. She has difficulties talking and especially walking. She is proactive, time bound, and consistent in work in spite of being disabled. She owns and operates a Rasta hairdo salon in her neighborhood at Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana.  Rasta hairdo is what most people call it. It is plaiting ones hair with mesh. Joyce is very skillful and a talented hairdresser who adds lots of beauty to the hair of her many customers. She says that is her secret. Joyce uses the weavons and meshes to plaits her client’s hair to add beauty to them and she has been in the job for the past five years now. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, so she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, mesh, hair cream, threads etc. to avoid shortages and poor servicing.
