texts.en: Lita S., 36, is married with four children. She has three years of experience in the plantation business and sells to the village people and the public two days per week. She requested her loan in order to buy tools - such as a shovel, a rake, and chemicals - as well as for home improvement. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about $145).  SPBD loans are Lita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks, and this is her first SPBD loan.

loans.use: To purchase such tools as a shovel, a rake, and chemicals.

loans.name: Esteria

texts.en:
Esteria P., 47, is widow with 5 children. Her son supports as a waiter but earned just enough for hand-to-mouth needs, and Esteria was striving hard to earn a living without a stable job. The education of her children and the day-to-day consumption was challenging, so she decided to open a store selling basic commodities.  

They were thankful that they joined Paglaum MPC. With very little capital, they were able to start their sari-sari (general store) business. Their daily sales goes the extra mile for the family's needs. They were also able to save with their extra income. They have applied to Paglaum MPC for additional capital of PHP 7,000. They say they were attracted to Paglaum MPC for its savings and insurance services of the cooperative. They want to gradually expand their little store and taste a good life someday.

loans.use: An additional and expansion of loan

loans.name: Melesete

texts.en: Melesete P. L., 53, is married with four children.  She has three years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public, three days per week. She has not had any previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~120 USD).  SPBD loans are Melesete’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tools for her business (e.g., shovel, rake, etc.) and insecticide

loans.name: Toshpulot

texts.ru: Тошпулот клиент в Микроинвест с 2004 года.Он проживает в кишлаке Тубчок, района Уткансой, который расположен в самом отдалённом уголке Таджикистана,вблизи гор.В этом районе в основном все мужчины в отъезде в Российскую Федерацию.Но т.к Тошпулот имеет хороший доход с земельного участка и с бизнеса животноводства , он считает, что хлеб можно наживать на Родине.У него большой земельный участок , с которого он получает урожай арахиса.Затем продаёт его своим клиентам по оптовым ценам.Каждый свой кредит он использует для увеличения поголовья скота.Тошпулот один из успешных клиентов в Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Toshpulot is a client of MicroInvest since 2004. He lives in a kishlak (village) of Tubchok in the Utkansoy region which is located in the most remote corner of Tajikistan near the mountains. In this region most of the men have left to the Russian Federation. But because Toshpulot has a good income from his plot of land and his animal husbandry business he thinks that he can earn his bread here in his motherland. He has a big plot of land from where he grows peanuts and collects the harvest. Then he sells it to his customers at wholesale prices. He uses every one of his loans to increase the heads of his cattle. Toshpulot is one of the successful clients of MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase head count of cattle

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Mrs. Yorn R. and her husband live in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with their two teenage children, both of whom are students in the local public school. Mrs. R. earns a living by making silk skirts by hand. On a typical day, she makes one or two skirts for her customers. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. To expand her business and  earn additional income, Mrs. R. is applying for a loan to buy more of the raw materials she uses to make skirts.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to use in making skirts.

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta Fetuao S., 39, is married with five children.  She has two years of experience in the canteen business. She sells at the village school six days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~140 USD).  SPBD loans are Elisapeta Fetuao’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase sweets and sacks of flour for donuts

loans.name: Gertrudez

texts.en:
Mrs. Gertrudes D., 31 years old, is married and lives at Dumalinao, Zamboanga del Sur. She has 2 children and raised them alone as her husband never returned home for years now. Because she could not get a good job, she decided to open food vending business.

With the family's financial difficulties, Mrs. D. joined Paglaum MPC to avail herself of financial assistance, but she was also happy knowing that she will also be able to save part of her income and obtain other benefits offered by the Cooperative. Now, she requests PHP 3,000 to purchase additional inventories. Her greatest desire is to see her children finish their studies and live a comfortable life ahead.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru: Мардонов Олимджон проживает  в районе Варзоб. Возраст 42 года, женат и имеет семерых детей.В семье работает один и приходится работать очень много, для того, чтобы обеспечить такую большую семью.Работает таксистом по маршруту Душанбе_ Варзоб. Кроме того, уже три года работает с пчелами. Имеет хозяйство и несколько семей пчел. Обратился к нам за кредитом для того, чтобы закупить сахар и дополнительную семью пчел. Это поможет ему увеличить хозяйство и таким образом увеличить получаемый урожай меда.
texts.en:
Olimjon lives in the Varzob region. He is 42 years old, married and has seven children. He is the sole support of his family and has to work a lot to support such a large one. He drives a taxi on the Dushanbe-Varzob route. In addition, for the past three years he has kept bees. He has a farm and several swarms of bees. He turned to us for a loan in order to purchase sugar and additional swarms. This will help him to expand his farm and thus increase his honey harvest.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar and additional swarms of bees

loans.name: Opetela

texts.en: Opetela F., 55, is married with seven children.  She has just started a food stall business. She sells to the general public, seven days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~210 USD).  SPBD loans are Opetela’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of flour and sugar, barrel of oil, gas stove, and pots

loans.name: Mirzokul

texts.en:
A. Mirzokul is a hard-working man who has dedicated himself to cattle raising so that he can support his three children. Mirzokul is currently seeking to buy cows that are pregnant so that he can expand his herd and have more cows to sell. He has applied for a loan from IMON International to make this possible. Please help him support his family by participating in the funding of this loan. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which began soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent have viable business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cows so that he can expand the business and improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Valijon

texts.en:
D. Valijon has always been hard-working and committed to ensure that his family never goes without its daily bread. He is married, has two children, and runs a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foods. With starting capital of $500, Valijon opened his shop 10 years ago. Since that time, it has continually expanded to the point where his wife (seen here in the photo) also helps out in the shop. Valijon has applied for a loan of $1,000 to buy additional products to sell in his store. He wants prospective lenders to know that he is ready to work even harder and make sacrifices  to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will be key success factors in his small business.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy additional food products to sell to his customers

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: Madame L. Kossiwa  habite le quartier d’ablogamé, elle a pour activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de pagnes, elle vend ses pagnes au rond point du port autonome de Lomé non loin du poste de douane où passe un nombre important de personnes. Pour bien couvrir la demande actuelle de sa clientèle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter 15 pièces de pagnes de qualités supérieures. Elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est  magasinier avec qui elle a eu 02 enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Kossiwa lives in the Ablogamé district. Her business is selling "pagnes" (brightly colored lengths of African print cloth). She sells her "pagnes" at the roundabout of the autonomous port of Lomé, not far from the customs office where a great number of people pass by.

In order to respond appropriately to the demand of her present customers, she is requesting her first loan from WAGES which will allow her to buy 15 lengths of high quality "pagne". She is married to a gentleman who is a stock clerk and with whom she has 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 'pagnes" for re-sale

loans.name: Khurshed

texts.en:
A. Khurshed is a 28-year-old potato farmer. He works hard to increase the size of his crop and support his wife and two children. Khurshed has managed his farm for the last five years. It allows him to feed his family today, but he also hopes that it will allow him to send his children to college so that they can find better jobs for their families in the future. Khurshed is asking for a loan of $2,500 to buy seeds and fertilizer. He will use the loan to increase his yield and better support his family. Let’s help this hard-working and talented young man achieve his dreams!

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have solid business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer to increase the output of his farm

loans.name: Ayiengeh

texts.en:
Ayiengeh works near the Belo Market selling drinks and beer from her small bar. She is married to Jub and has five children. With this loan, Ayiengeh plans to buy drinks including beer, benches for seating, cups and the crates used for transporting drink bottles.

Having been in this business for a long time, Ayiengeh understands her customers' needs and believes that she offers them good prices. She believes her business will do well because of her experience and because she knows how to treat her customers well.

It has not been a smooth ride financially for Ayiengeh. In the past, she has seen road bumps trying to pay for the things her children need, including their school fees. This will be her second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. She has used her profits to pay for her children’s needs, especially their school fees. She also plans to take better care of her herself and possibly to add to her business. Ayiengeh takes out GHAPE loans because of the training they provide and she appreciates how they've taught her to save better.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multifaceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy beer, cups, and crates and to improve seating

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.en:
U. Olimjon is 30 years old. He is married with four children. Ever since he was young, he has been farming and raising animals. He has 4 hectares of land where he produces wheat and onions. And also he raises cattle and, little by little over time, he has been improving and expanding the business with the goal of improving his family’s standard of living and continuing to pay for his children’s school expenses.

IMON International has been a fundamental part of Olimjon´s business, having provided loans which have been used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and calves. Today, once again, Olimjon faces this need, and he trusts that his loan will be granted so that he can help his business and his family.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase calves in order to expand his business

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibrahima S. « Go » est professeur de Français à Bambey, une petite ville de 100 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Il a enseigné les étudiants au lycée de Bambey depuis 5 ans.  Il a déjà reçu un crédit auprès de l’IMCEC qu’il a bien remboursé, et maintenant il sollicite son deuxième crédit pour l’équipement de sa maison.  Monsieur S. a 32 ans et il est célibataire.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima S. "Go" is a French teacher in Bambey, a small city located 100 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He has been teaching students at the Bambey lycée (high school) for five years. He had received a loan from IMCEC that he repaid. And now he's requesting his second loan for equipping his house. Mr. S. is 32 years old and unmarried.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To equip his house

loans.name: Diborah

texts.en:
Diborah is married to Titus and has eight children. She describes herself as a “petit trader” who sells goods from her small store in Belo, Cameroon. With this loan, Diborah plans to purchase items for resale: one bag of rice, cigas (or cigarettes), one tin of groundnuts (peanuts), six packets of Maggi (a popular flavouring in Cameroon), and eleven packets of Sampoka.

Having had her business for some time, Diborah thinks her business will succeed. She says that she is not only welcoming to her customers, but that she is open to advice, especially from her GHAPE group members. By not charging exorbitant prices and staying in business, she knows that her business helps her community to save money.

Diborah has had some difficult challenges in her life. She has seen the death of a child and her niece. She even experienced her house catching fire and her savings being burned.

This is Diborah's second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. With the profits from this loan, she plans to buy food, medicine and clothing for her children, as well as pay for their school fees. She chooses GHAPE loans because she not only benefits from the profits of the loans, but she enjoys being a member in a group of entrepreneurs.

About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Items for resale in general store

loans.name: Foinsah Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married and has seven children. She lives in Belo, Cameroon and sets up shop in the Belo Market. Grace runs a “Buyem and Sellem” store where she sells all sorts of goods. With this loan she plans to purchase clothing, specifically for women and children, in order to sell them to the community in Belo. She will also use part of the loan for covering the transportation costs she will incur while buying the clothing. 

Having grown a solid customer base, Grace can see that her business will be successful. She is a savvy business woman who is confident in her business skills. She also notes that the location of her business, near the market, is advantageous. 

Although Grace has many children, she still has a hard time thinking about the death of one of her sons. From the time he was born he was really sick. After 12 years he finally passed away. 

This is Grace's second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. With the profits from this loan, she plans to pay for her children’s school fees and test both her children and herself for HIV. She also has plans to add to her family farm. Grace takes out GHAPE loans because after comparing them to other microfinance NGOs she thinks the training they give makes them the best. 

About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Children and women’s clothing and transportation costs

loans.name: Nazir

texts.en:
K. Nazir is a hard-working man who is in agriculture. He has worked at this business for a long time and acquired his abilities in ranching and farming when he was very young. He is a married father with responsibilities for supporting his 5 children. Nazir is known as being very responsible and hard-working, since every day very early in the morning he starts his job taking care of his fields while at the same time raising cattle in his own pen located at his house. IMON International has been the backbone of his business because of having granted loans which have allowed him to improve his standard of living through the acquisition of cattle and vegetables for planting. Today, once again, Nazir trusts that his credit will be approved and he will be able to improve his business with the purchase of cattle and farm supplies to plant.

loans.use: Cattle and farm supplies to expand the business

loans.name: Saidbek

texts.en:
K. Saidbek is a young, married man who breeds calves in a small village in Zafarabad district of Sugd region. Saidbek is young but full of energy; he tries every single day to make the life of his family better.

He started his business three years ago. He continued the business of his father, who is a pensioner. Saidbek has great experience in cattle breeding because he learned it from his childhood.

Saidbek would like to expand his business and purchase more calves. This will help him to increase his income and improve his life conditions. We wish him good luck and appreciate your help!

loans.use: To purchase more calves in order to expand his business

loans.name: Huguette

texts.fr:
Q. Huguette est née le 16/07/1968 à ouidah, dans le Département de l’Atlantique. Huguette a été à l’école jusqu'en classe de quatrième année du lycée. Mais très tôt Huguette a abandonné les classes par manque de soutient financier. Huguette est mariée, mère de quatre enfants dont trois scolarisés. Le quatrième enfant n'a pas encore l'âge d'aller à l'école. Après l’abandon de l’école, Huguette accompagne sa mère pour vendre les tissus dans les marchés les plus reculés du BENIN. Il y a quinze (15) ans Huguette s’est mise à son propre compte. Contrairement à ce que vend sa mère, Huguette vend les divers: bombons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, etc. C'est pour élever le niveau de son activité et mieux subvenir à ses besoins que huguette sollicite un prêt.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Q. Huguette was born on June 16, 1968 in Ouidah, in Atlantique County. She has attend school through the 8th grade. But she quit early due to a lack of financial support. She is married and the mother of four children, three of whom are in school. The fourth child is not yet school-age. After dropping out of school, Huguette joined her mother in selling cloth at the most remote marketplaces of Benin. And fifteen years ago, she got started on her own. Contrary to what her mother sells, Huguette sells various goods: candy, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardines, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, and soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, etc. To raise her level of business and to provide for herself better, she's requesting a loan.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy canned foods, cosmetics, cloth, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda is a young widow and has one child. She runs a business selling food that she cooks. Hilda lives and works in Belo, Cameroon, a village north of GHAPE headquarters. With this loan she plans to purchase food for her restaurant, including one bag of beans, one bag of rice and two bags of corn.

With the experience of running her business, Hilda has seen success. She has established a customer base and has studied business skills, she says. As she has experienced poverty, the inability to clothe herself, as well as having to raise her child alone (for her husband died while she was pregnant), she knows how to overcome obstacles.

This is Hilda's second loan from GHAPE since 2007. With the profits from this loan, she plans to pay for her child’s school fees as well as help her family with its farm. Also, she plans to add to her business by buying more cooking equipment and supplies. Hilda chooses to take out GHAPE loans because of the business and social training she receives.


About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans and corn for her restaurant

loans.name: Ayao

texts.fr: Monsieur A. ayao exerce dans la mécanique, il a ouvert  un garage dans lequel il exerce son activité, il a associé  à   son activité de mécanique le commerce de pièces détachées  qu’il profite en même temps pour vendre à ses clients. Voulant se réapprovisionner en pièces détachées et acheter du matériel de travail, il sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter des moteurs, des amortisseurs, du matériel mécanique et d’autres pièces détachées. Il est marié et a 04 enfants, sa femme est une revendeuse.
texts.en:
Mr. A. Ayao works in mechanics. He opened a garage where he works at his trade, to which he has included commerce in spare parts that is all the while advantageous to him for selling to customers. Wanting to resupply himself with spare parts and to buy work materials, he's requesting his first loan to buy motors, shock absorbers, mechanical equipment, and other spare parts. He is married and has four children. His wife is in sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy motors, shock absorbers, spare parts, and work materials

loans.name: Safarkul

texts.en:
Safarkul B., 54 and married with six children, is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children. He has great experience in cattle breeding, having been involved in it for 31 years, and over time he has increased his sales significantly. Since the business has been going well, he would like it to expand it and so is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy young cattle. He and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in continuing this business and helping them give the children a better quality of life. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes:  its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:
Bridget is married to Martin and they have six children. She runs a business selling food in the local Belo Market in her village. With this Kiva loan, Bridget intends to purchase bags of beans, corn and Irish (potatoes) for resale.

Having a good location in the market and knowing the popularity of her produce, Bridget is confident that her business will be successful. With her first loan from GHAPE she purchased similar items and did well repaying the loan. With the proceeds from her last loan she expanded her business.

Bridget mentions that she lives in tough circumstances, always “suffering in the hands of thieves.” She also had to experience the passing of her child. She wants to be able to provide for her children now. With the profits from this loan, Bridget wants to pay for her children’s school fees and hopes to continue expanding her business. GHAPE loans are good for Bridget because the conditions are agreeable to her.


About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase beans, corn and Irish (potatoes) for resale

loans.name: Safarali

texts.en:
D. Safarali has been in the livestock business for many years. He supports his wife and four children. Since he began his business, he has worked hard to use his earnings to sustain his home. His livestock business has helped him to achieve his goals.

Currently, Safarali needs to purchase more livestock in order to grow his business and improve the living conditions of his family. He is seeking a loan from IMON International in order to acquire additional animals to offer in the markets.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Abdullojon

texts.en:
D. Abdullojon is 43 years old and cares for his wife and four children. He is a very hardworking man. He has land on which he grows potatoes and other vegetables. His wife sells their products. When she goes to sell their products, he remains behind to farm. What most aggravates him about this activity is that when the opportunity to sell things arrives, sometimes he makes a lot and sometimes the market isn’t as kind to him.

Abdullojon and his wife work hard for the education of their children. With the loan requested from Kiva, he would buy seed and fertilizer for his fields of potatoes. Abdullojon has hopes that the price of potatoes will hold up, because he says that this will make this agriculture worth the sacrifice.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Abdukahor

texts.en:
H. Abdukahor is a farmer. He grows potatoes and other vegetables to support his family. He is 25 years old and has three children. He is worried about getting money to sustain his 2-hectare farm business. His wife supports him in all his decisions. Together, they work hard to raise their children well. He has been tilling the land for four years.

Abdukahor is asking a loan of $1000 USD that he will use to buy more seed and fertilizer. The loan will allow him to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Islom

texts.ru: Ислом 26 летний молодой человек, отец двоих детей. Занимается откормом и продажей скота. А также имеет бизнес по продаже плетёного камыша, которого используют для покрытия полов новых домов .Т.к. в районах  Учбог вместо деревянных полов оставляют землю и покрывают данным покрытием, и застеливают коврами. Это изделие имеет большой спрос у сельского населения. Ислом решил получить кредит для увеличения товарооборота скота.
texts.en:
Islom is a young man of 26 years of age, a father of two children. He is raising and selling cattle. He also has a business selling woven cane which is used to cover the floors of new homes. Because in the regions of Uchbog this type of covering is used instead of the wooden floors and then covered with rugs. This product has a high demand among the village population. Islom decided to get a loan to increase the commodity circulation of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cattle

loans.name: Gani

texts.en:
J. Gani, aged 47 years, is married with five children, all of them in school through the universal primary education.

Gani earns his living through farming, specifically planting potatoes, carrots and onions. He seeks room for expanding the business and creating an opportunity for his market especially during the times he is waiting to harvest. He needs an alternative that can help him save for his children's higher education.

Gani requests a $1000 USD loan that he will spend on purchasing seed and fertilizer for his crop.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Vali

texts.en:
J. Vali is 74 years old. He’s married and has six children and several wonderful grandchildren. Vali is a farmer. He grows various crops like potatoes, carrots and wheat. His youngest son helps him with the business. Having been working on that business for more than 20 years, Vali has gained rich experience. Though he’s at retirement age, he’s not going to stop with the business as he is a diligent man and he can’t imagine his life without work.

Now Vali requests $1000 US Dollars for purchasing the input materials like seed and mineral fertilizer for growing his crops. After gathering his harvest he wants to sell them to the local inhabitants at lower prices than in the market. Vali promises to be accurate with repaying the loan and thanks everyone for support.

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Adji Penda

texts.fr: Adji Penda Dramé a 33 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle souhaiterait avec ce prêt renforcer le capital de son activité de vente d’huile de palme. Ce petit commerce lui permet de subvenir à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Adji Penda Dramé, age 33, is married and has five children. She would like to use this loan to bolster her working capital for selling palm oil. This small business enables her to improve living conditions for her and her family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell palm oil

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
J. Yusuf is a hardworking 46 year old man who has considerably improved his economic situation by growing potatoes and carrots. Yusuf grows native varieties and sells them at the market. He feels happy to have the privilege of being a father to four children. He is saving money in order to become a taxi driver in the future, should his efforts in the field no longer be fruitful. In order to have a successful harvest, Yusuf is asking for a loan of $1000 USD to buy sacks of seeds and organic fertilizer for his crop.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Afde No 22 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 22 est constitué de dix femmes, dont la plus jeune a 27 ans et la plus âgée a 57 ans.  Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Grand Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente de céréales locales.  Elles sont bien expérimentées et très sollicitées dans cette activité. Dans le cadre de l’amélioration de la qualité de leurs services et l’agrandissement de la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe confiance ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance l’IMCEC.  Elles ont déjà reçu un prêt de groupement auprès de l’IMCEC, et elles l’ont bien remboursé. Elles comptent utiliser ce prêt pour reconstituer leur stock d’arachides, pain de singe (le fruit de Baobab), mil, et oignions qu’elles vont vendre en détail, au comptant au marché grand Thiès.  Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 15,000 CFA ($30) au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
"Association Femme Développement Entreprise Numéro 22" is a group composed of ten women. The youngest is 27 years old, and the oldest is 57. They live in large traditional extended families in the Grand Thiés district of Thiès, a city located 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. The women know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they do almost the same work, selling local grains. They are very experienced and in high demand in this field.

With regard to improving the quality of their services and expanding their businesses, the members of this reliance group decided to join the micro-finance institution IMCEC. They had received a group loan from IMCEC before and repaid it.

With this loan, the group members plan to replenish their stock of peanuts, monkey bread (the fruit of the baobab tree), millet, and onions that they will sell retail, cash accepted, at the grand marketplace of Thiès.

The group member hope to realize an average profit of 15,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the family, and to invest the rest in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local grains

loans.name: Komil

texts.en:
K. Komil is a young man who has been a farmer for five years. He is happily married to a hardworking woman who always supports him. She has helped him get ahead in life and has given him three children.

Like most other people in the zone who depend on vegetable crops, Komil needs to buy agricultural supplies that will allow for the maintenance and production of his crops up to the optimum harvest time. With this purpose Komil applied to IMON International for a loan of $1000 USD to purchase agricultural supplies like seed and fertilizer. Komil and his beloved family sincerely thank you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Marifat

texts.ru: Маърифат  женщина 33 лет , мать троих детей. Муж уехал на заработки в Россию. Сама Маърифат работает в колхозе на поле. Её дети учатся в средней школе. Она  кроме своей работы дополнительно занимается откормом и продажей скота. У неё сейчас три коровы и пять баранов. Узнав от соседей , что можно для расширения бизнеса можно получить кредит, она решила обратиться в Микроинвест. Её муж каждый месяц минимально посылает ей на жизнь 400-500 сомони. Поэтому Маърифат уверенно обратилась за кредитом , зная, что сможет погасить его без проблем.
texts.en:
Marifat is a 33-year-old woman, the mother of three children. Her husband is away working in Russia. Marifat herself works in the fields on a collective farm, while her children study at the secondary school. In addition to her regular job, she raises and sells cattle. At present Marifat has three cows and five sheep. She learned from her neighbors about the possibility of taking out a loan to expand her business and decided to deal with MicroInvest. Each month her husband sends her at least 400-500 somoni for living expenses, therefore Marifat turned to MicroInvest with confidence, knowing that she could repay the loan without difficulty.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling cattle

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
N. Christine est née vers 1945 à Agonlin dans le Département du zou. Christine est allée à l'école jusqu'en deuxième année du lycée. Christine est mariée à GOUNDJO Joachim. Christine a sept (7) enfants avec son mari, tous scolarisés: cinq filles et deux garçons. Les filles sont toutes mariées; c'est les deux garçons qui sont encore à la charge de leur mère. Après avoir abandonné l'école, Christine aida sa mère à vendre les céréales. Mais depuis trente ans, Christine vend les condiments de sauce (tomates fraîches, piments, oignons, épices, etc.) pour son propre compte.Pour élever le niveau de son activité et faire face aux besoins de ses enfants Christine sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
N. Christine was born around 1945 in Agonlin, in Zou County. She attended school through the 10th grade. She is married to GOUNDJO Joachim, and with her husband, she has seven children, all schooled: five girls and two boys. All the girls are married, and the two boys are the ones who are still supported by their mother. After dropping out of school, Christine helped her mother sell grain. But for thirty years, she has been on her own selling sauce condiments (fresh tomatoes, chili peppers, onions, spices, etc.) To raise her business activity and to cope with the needs of her children, she's requesting a loan from Alidé.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy coconut oil, peanut oil, a sack of cassava flour, and a sack of salt

loans.name: Mardonkul

texts.en:
M. Mardonkul is a 62-year-old man. His wife works as a housekeeper, and they have four children. His family plans include moving forward with crop production so that he can financially support his children’s studies.

The biggest problem Mardonkul faces is that pest insects have affected his crops, and he does not have enough money to deal with the problem. He has been working in agriculture for 20 years. He is requesting this loan in order to use it for his crops, thus thwarting losses.

Agriculture is his family’s source of income. For this reason, Mardonkul gives thanks to IMON and Kiva for the support it gives him via this loan, which will be of great benefit to his crops.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after Tajikistan’s independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To deal with pest insects that have affected his crops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy boards and work tools

loans.name: Nigora

texts.en:
S. Nigora is 21 years old and is not yet married. She is a market vendor. Nigora sells women’s clothing and shoes in the local market. She has been in the business for three years.

Nigora is a friendly and polite woman. She is trying to diversify her range of goods in order to satisfy the needs of her clients who have various levels of income. However, the majority of the goods are attractive to the customers with average incomes. The business is stable allowing Nigora to make a considerable contribution to the family budget.

Now Nigora is planning to purchase new clothing in order to increase her stock of spring clothes for women. For this purpose she requests $1000 U.S. dollars for the term of 10 months. Nigora thanks all those supporting her and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To increase her stock of spring clothes

loans.name: Juraboy

texts.en:
S. Juraboy is 51 years old, married, and has six children. For more than 30 years, Juraboy has been raising calves and selling them at the market. This is the way he feeds his family. Since his business is doing well, he wishes to expand it. Thus, Juraboy has decided to ask for a loan of $1200 US to buy more calves. He hopes to increase his income and improve his family's living conditions with this loan. The purchase will enable Juraboy to increase his sales, earn more, and to meet the needs of his dear children, for whose sake he is working so hard.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Ngu

texts.en:
Married with five children, T. supports his family by manufacturing cooking pots as well as selling chickens and rabbits in Bamenda. He is planning on using this loan to purchase twenty chickens, animal feed and medication, four rabbits, and oxygen and firewood for welding.

Since July of 2007, T. has been a member of GHAPE, and he recently completed the repayments on his first loan. He is confident that his businesses will continue to do well because he has a lot of experience, his products are in high demand, and he enjoys his work!

By increasing the productivity of his work, T. is helping the ecosystem of small businesses in the community. In addition to selling his intended products to customers, he buys feed from entrepreneurs and then sells the manure from his chickens to farmers for their crops.

On a personal note, T. has faced some of life's difficulties: poverty, lack of education, and the death of his father and first son, but because of this loan and the support of others, he has been able to confront such problems. In fact, he plans to use the profits from the loan to pay for his children's school fees and medical services, buy additional food, clothe his family, and and continue to save money!

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: procuring  chickens, rabbits, chicken feed, oxygen, firewood

loans.name: Abdukayum

texts.ru:
Эшмонов Абдукаюм мужчина 38 лет , женат имеет пятерых детей. Работает на стройке жилых домов. Кроме этого у него доход с бизнеса животноводства. Он покупает дешёвый молодой скот и через 3-4 месяца , откормив его продаёт за хорошую цену. Жена занимается продажей козьей пряжи , а также работает в колхозе.
Абдукаюм хочет получить кредит отремонтировать свой  хлев . где содержит скот и закупить корм.
texts.en:
Abdukayum E. is a 38-year-old man, married, and has five children. He works in home construction. In addition he has income from raising livestock. He buys inexpensive young cattle and, after 3-4 months of fattening, sells them at a profit. His wife sells cashmere yarn, and also works on a collective farm. Abdukayum want to take out a loan to make repairs to the shed where he keeps the cattle and to purchase feed.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling cattle

loans.name: Lum

texts.en:
As a widow, F. supports her six children by selling produce from her farm in her community in Bamenda. She will use this loan to purchase seeds for cocoyams, corn, beans, four bags of manure, one bag of fertilizer and for labor to clear and till her farmland.

F. is helping her community by creating employment opportunities on her farm and also by selling her produce at a convenient location for her customers. Prior to her involvement with GHAPE, she was unable to provide an education for her children. She also lost two dear people in her life—her husband and first son.

With the profits of this loan, F. now can provide a better life for her family by paying for their educational fees and books, and expanding her farm! F. appreciates GHAPE's gradual repayment schedule.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: buying seeds, corn, beans, manure, fertilizer, and paying for farm labor

loans.name: Enazar

texts.ru: Эназар мужчина 35 лет, женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена работает в сельской школе учительницей. Сам Эназар полностью занимается бизнесом животноводства.Он покупает скот и откормив его , продаёт его на рынке через несколько месяцев. Он сам работает сварщиком на заказ. С чего имеет доход на жизнь. Эназар   хорошо разбирается в породистых скотах. У него очень крупные , откормленные бараны. Которые он продаёт мясникам для убоя и продажи мяса. Для увеличения  скота Эназар решил взять кредит.
texts.en:
Enazar is a 35-year-old man, and married with four children. His wife works as a teacher at the agricultural school. Enazar himself works full-time raising livestock. He purchases cattle, fattens them and sells them at the market in several months' time. He also works part-time as a welder, which brings in income for living expenses. Enazar has a good understanding of purebred cattle. He has very large, fat sheep, which he sells to butchers to slaughter for the meat. Enazar decided to take out a loan to increase the size of his flock.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new washing machine

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Monsieur S.  a appris la soudure, il a ouvert en 2006 son propre atelier de soudure, il fabrique des fourneaux et des portes de maison qu’il vend à ses clients. Ne disposant plus suffisamment de matières nécessaires à la fabrication de fourneaux et portes de maison, il sollicite son premier crédit de WAGES pour acheter des 15 tôles  20 barres de fer et d’autres matériaux. Ainsi il pourra augmenter ses recettes. Il est un jeune homme célibataire et très dynamique
texts.en:
Mr. S. learned how to weld. In 2006, he opened his own welding workshop. He makes stoves, doors, and gates for homes that he sells to his customers. No longer having sufficient equipment and supplies needed for making these products, he's requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy 15 pieces of sheet metal, 20 iron bars, and other materials. Thus, he'll be able to augment his receipts. He is a young, unmarried man who is very dynamic.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheet metal and iron bars

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr:
K. Alice est née le 20 Juin 1970 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Alice est allée à l’école jusqu'en première année du lycée. Alice a abandonné l’école par manque de soutient financier. Alice est mariée et mère de six enfants dont quatre scolarisés; les deux autres n'ont pas encore l'âge d'aller à l'école. Après l’abandon de l’école, Alice aidait sa mère pour la vente de noix d'acajou grillés. Mais depuis 1989, Alice s’est mise à son propre compte, toujours pour la vente de noix d’acajou grillés.  Alice grille les noix d’acajou qu’elle met en bouteille pour vendre. Alice enregistre une forte demande de ce produit. C’est pourquoi Alice a besoin de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle en a pour acheter de noix d’acajou; afin de mieux faire fasse à la demande de sa clientèle.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
K. Alice was born on June 20, 1970 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She attended school through the 11th grade, although she dropped out due to a lack of financial support. She is married and the mother of six children, four of whom are in school; the other two are not yet school-age. After dropping out, Alice used to help her mother with selling roasted cashew nuts. But in 1989, she got started on her own, again selling roasted cashews. She grills the nuts and then places them into bottles for sale. She notes the high demand for this product. This is why she needs more funds than she has to buy cashews, so as to address the demands of her customers.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of cashew nuts

loans.name: Ngwa

texts.en:
J. is married with four children under the age of fifteen and makes his living by manufacturing cooking pots and raising pigs in Bamenda. Since March of 2007, J. has been a GHAPE borrower and recently completed the repayment of his first loan.

He will use this current loan to purchase charcoal, zinc, transport of the zinc, and one piglet. Because of his experience as a blacksmith and his large customer base, J. is confident his business will continue to succeed.

In the past, J. has faced issues like lack of education, inadequate capital for his business, bad health and debt. However, J. remains positive: with the profits from this loan, he will be able to pay for his children's school fees, more food in the house, medication, and clothing for his family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Charcoal, Zinc, Transport and Piglets

loans.name: Balaba

texts.fr: Balaba G. est une femme mariée de 45 ans. Son activité consisté à transformer l’arachide en pâte qu’elle vend après. Les revenus générés lui permettent de satisfaire les charges familiales.
texts.en:
Balaba G. is a married woman, 45 years of age. Her work involves processing peanuts into peanut butter, which she sells afterwards. The revenues generated will enable her to meet family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To process peanuts into peant butter for sale

loans.name: Neba

texts.en:
Separated from her husband, F. supports her five children by selling medicine, cosmetics and cell phone credit at her shop in Bamenda. She is planning on using this loan to purchase additional medicine, rubbing oil and cell phone credit.

F. is well aware of what it takes to manage a business well: she believes one must know the business language, keep a good stock of needed products, and make customers feel welcome. With this knowledge, she hopes that her shop will continue to succeed. In fact, if the business expands, she will help the community by creating employment opportunities at her shop.

On a personal note, F. has faced some of life's difficulties like poverty, mistreatment by others, and the inability to provide for her children, but because of this loan and the support of others, she has been able to confront such problems. Three out of F.'s five children are under the age of fifteen, so she plans to use the profits from the loan to pay for her children's school fees and medical services, buy additional food, expand her business and and continue to save her money!

F. appreciates GHAPE's gradual repayment schedule and their training programs, for instance how to manage their loan and savings.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Medicine, Rubbing Oil, Cell Phone Credit

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cloth and ingredients for dyeing cloth

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr:
K. Colette est née le 06/09/1968 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Colette est originaire de Ouidah dans le Département de l’Atlantique. Colette a fait jusqu’en quatrième année du lycée. Ensuite, Colette a fait une formation professionnelle en secrétariat puis une formation en couture.  Colette est mariée à AGUESSI Antoine, un administrateur des impôts. Colette a deux enfants tous scolarisés: AGUESSI Maximilienne, âgée de dix huit(18) ans en cinquième année du lycée; AGUESSI Arorld, âgée de onze (11) ans en sixième année du cours primaire. Aujourd’hui Colette est dans la vente de divers articles tels que: les produits cosmétiques, les mèches pour tresser les cheveux et les produis pour les cheveux. Colette a déjà deux crédits avec ALIDé. Pour mieux développer son commerce Colette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
K. Colette was born on September 6, 1968 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She traces her roots to Ouidah, in Atlantique County. Colette finished the 8th grade in school. Next, she took professional secretarial training and then training in how to sew. She is married to AGUESSI Antoine, a tax administrator, and has two children, both in school: AGUESSI Maximilienne, age 18, in the 7th grade; and AGUESSI Arorld, age 11, in the 6th grade. Today, Colette sells various goods, such as: cosmetics, hair extensions for braiding hair, and hair products. She has had two loans with Alidé. To develop her commerce, she's requesting a third loan from Alidé.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions, hair products, and cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To supply her shop

loans.name: Hayot

texts.ru: Хаёт женщина 46 лет , замужем , имеет двоих детей.Имеет средне-специальное образование. Муж работает водителем городского троллейбуса. Зарабатывает немного. Чтобы прокормить и обучать детей в школе Хаёт занимается перепродажей хлеба в центре города Худжанда на рынке "Панчшанбе". У нее очень качественный и вкусный хлеб, который пользуется большим спросом. каждый свой займ она использует для увеличения своего товарооборота. Раньше у нее была одна точка реализации, а на сегодня она имеет продавца, который торгует недалеко от нее. Следующий займ она хочет потратить на расширение своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Hayot is 46 years old, married, and has two children. She received a secondary vocational education. Her husband drives a city trolley. Hayot earns enough selling bread at the Panchshanbe market in downtown Khujand to feed and educate her children. She retails very high-quality, delicious bread, which is in high demand. Each loan she has taken out has been used to increase her turnover. In the past she had only one sales outlet, but today she employs another saleswoman who works nearby. She would like to spend the next loan on expanding her business.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bread retailer

loans.name: Ngwa

texts.en:
As a single mother of one son, E. supports her family by selling cosmetics at the market in Bamenda. She is planning on using this loan to purchase rubbing oil and glycerine oil, which she will then re-sell at the market. Both products are used for the skin and glycerine is an emollient oil.

E. believes her business will continue to succeed because she is an experienced businesswoman, has a large customer base and is very focused on its management. She hopes to improve her own and her family's health and standard of living.

In the past, E. has faced deep poverty, sickness and deaths in her family, but with the support of GHAPE and Kiva, she has met and will continue to confront such challenges. With the profits from this loan, she will be able to pay the school fees of her only son, who is under the age of fifteen years old.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Rubbing Oil and Glycerine

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
H. Christine est née vers 1953 à Abomey, la cité historique du Bénin dans le Département du Zou. Christine n’est jamais allée à l’école. Christine est veuve et mère de trois enfants: deux filles, toutes mariées et un garçon qui est encore à sa charge. Dès son enfance Christine accompagnait sa mère pour vendre les tissus. A vingt cinq (25) ans  Christine s'est mise à son propre compte jusqu'au jour d’aujourd’hui. Christine a eu déjà trois crédits à ALIDé qu’elle a bien remboursé et grâce auxquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son commerce. Pour développer et diversifier son activité, Christine sollicite encore un nouveau prêt auprès de ALIDé. 


 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
H. Christine was born around 1953 in Abomey, the historic city of Benin in Zou County. She never went to school. She is a widow and the mother of three children: two girls, both married, and a boy who is still in her care. Since her childhood, Christine used to accompany her mother selling cloth. At the age of 25, Christine got started on her own and still is today. She has had three loans with Alidé that she repaid. And thanks to these loans, she was able to raise her business activity. To develop and diversify her business, she's again requesting a new loan from Alidé.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of HITARGET-brand cloth and fabrics for curtains and mosquito netting

loans.name: Modou

texts.fr: Monsieur Modou B. est un commerçant qui sollicite son premier crédit auprès de l’IMCEC.  Il gérait une cantine a Dakar de 2000 a 2005 eu marche.  Depuis 2005, il fait la navette entre Touba Tivaoune et Thies.  Son activité consiste à vendre de diverses marchandises comme d’arachide, patte d’arachide, pain de singe (le fruit de Baobab), et café.  Avec ce prêt, il envisage renforcer son activité et aussi faire la toiture de la chambre de sa mère.  Monsieur B. est célibataire et il habite au quartier Cité Lamy à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.
texts.en:
Mr Modou B. is a merchant who's seeking his first loan from Kiva's partner, IMEC. He used to run a small shop in Dakar from 2000 to 2005. Since 2005, he's been traveling back and forth between Touba Tivaoune and Thiès. His business consists in selling various products such as peanuts, peanut butter, "monkey bread" (baobab tree fruit), and coffee. With this loan, he intends to bolster his business, and also to put a new roof on his mother's bedroom. Mr. B. is unmarried and lives in the Cité Lamy neighborhood in Thiès, a city located 70 kilometers from Dakar, the capital of Senegal.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products for his food selling business, and to repair his house

loans.name: Ablavi Dodji

texts.fr: Madame K. ablavi dodji est une dame qui réside dans le quartier d’ADAKPAME, elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est déclarant en douane, elle a 2 enfants.Elle a ouvert depuis 2000 une boutique dans laquelle elle exerce le commerce des articles de mercerie. Elle veut agrandir son commerce par l’achat des articles de mercerie et de 30 tissus. Ayant déjà obtenu un crédit de WAGES qu’elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite son deuxième crédit pour réaliser ces achats.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ablavi Dodji K. is a woman who lives in the ADAKPAME neighborhood. She's married to a gentleman who is a customs officer, and she has two children. In 2000, she opened a store where she sells sewing supplies. She wants to bolster her business by buying sewing supplies and 30 pieces of fabric. Having repaid her previous loan without problem, she's seeking her second loan to buy theses items.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies and 30 pieces of fabric

loans.name: Fama

texts.fr: Fama T. a 39ans, mariée, mère d’un enfant avec 4 autres dont elle a la charge. Elle fait de la restauration et aimerait avec ce prêt parvenir à mieux renforcer son capital. Avec cet activité, elle compte subvenir aux besoins familiaux afin de mieux améliorer les conditions de vie de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Fama T., age 39, is married and the mother of one child. She also has four other children to support. She works in the food serving business, and would like to use this loan to bolster her working capital. She intends to use this business to provide for her family, in order to improve the living standard of her children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her food serving business

loans.name: Salif Richard

texts.fr: Monsieur Salif Richard A. est un électricien bobineur qui habite au quartier Mbour 1 de Thiès, une ville à 70km de Dakar. Il est marié et a 45ans et a commencé son métier d’électricien bobineur depuis plus de 20 ans. Il travaille avec des entreprises  et des particuliers, et il a déjà contacté des prêts qu’il a remboursés normalement. Avec ce prêt il veut acheter des matériels pour renforcer ses activités dans son entreprise. Avec ses revenues il entretien sa famille et compte agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif Richard A. is an electrician who lives in the Mbour 1 neighborhood in Thiès, a city located 70 kilometers from Dakar. He's 45 years old and married, and he's been an electrician for 20 years. He works with companies and individuals, and already obtained loans that were repaid without problems. With this loan, he wants to buy supplies to bolster his business. With his profits, he provides for his family and intends to expand his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electric supplies

loans.name: Makiese Plus Group

texts.fr: Wivine M. a 47 ans, veuve et mère d’une fille âgée de 24 ans qui est encore étudiante. Elle vend des beignets, saucisses ainsi que d’œufs. Son capital actuel représente une valeur de $200. Wivine vend dans un quartier au centre de Kinshasa où elle a beaucoup de clients. Elle a commencé pour la toute première fois la vente des poulets en 1989. Son capital initial était de $40. De 1990 à 1993, avec le bénéfice accumulé de son affaire, Wivine a décidé de diversifier son affaire en ajoutant des saucisses qu’elle achetait en gros et les livrait aux magasins d’alimentations. Cela lui procurait assez de revenus jusqu’à $1000. En 1993, Wivine fut victime des pillages à Kinshasa et perdit toute sa marchandise et resta sans fonds ni marchandise. C’est ainsi de 1994 à 2004, elle tentait de vendre des cartons des savons sans succès et était déséquilibrée avec la mort de son mari en 2003. Elle changeant d’activité en 2005 pour se lancer dans la vente d’épices qui lui procurât un capital important de $ 2400 qui malheureusement furent emportés par des voleurs. Vers la fin de la même année, Wivine reprit l’activité de fabrication des beignets avec un faible capital de $20 jusqu’à ce jour. Son affaire croit rapidement et produit un bénéfice de $30 par semaine. Le crédit qu’elle a obtenu lui a permis d’acheter 1 sac de farine de froment, 1 bidon d’huile végétale raffinée de 25 litres, du sucre et autres ingrédients pour la fabrication des beignets dans le but d’accroitre le bénéfice. Son rêve est d’ouvrir un dépôt des boissons afin de livrer aux détaillants.
texts.en:
Wivine M., 47, is the widowed mother of a daughter who is 24 and who is still a student. She sells fried dough and sausages and eggs. Her present working capital amounts to about US$ 200.

Wivine has her sales point in a neighborhood in the center of Kinshasa where she has lots of customers. She began by selling chickens in 1989. Her intital capital was US$ 40. From 1990 to 1993, with the profits she had accumulated from her business, Wivine diversified and added the sale of sausages which she bought wholesale and delivered to grocery stores. This brought her working capital up to US$ 1,000.

In 1993, Wivine fell victim to the pillaging in Kinshasa and lost all her merchandise. She was left without merchandise and without funds. Thus, from 1994 to 2004, she tried selling cases of soap without success. In 2003 she was caught off balance at the death of her husband. She changed her business in 2005 to begin selling spices which brought her to a significant capital of US$ 2,400--which sadly was stolen by robbers.

Around the end of that same year, Wivine took up selling fried dough again with the insignificant working capital of $20, a business she has continued until this day. Her business is growing rapidly and producing a profit of US$ 30 per week. The loan that she has received has allowed her to buy 1 sack of wheat flour, 1 jerrycan of 25 liters of refined vegetable oil, sugar, and other ingredients for making fried dough in order to grow her profit. Her dream is to open up a drinks depot so as to be able to supply retailers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing one sack of wheat flour, 1 jerrycan of 25 liters of vegetable oil, and some sugar

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy work tools and planks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase of cloth and the necessary items for dyeing it

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr:
O. Véronique est née vers 1950 à Ouidah dans le Département de l'Atlantique. Véronique n'est pas scolarisée. Véronique accompagnait sa mère pour vendre les tissus déjà qu'elle avait sept ans. Véronique est veuve et mère de sept (7) enfants qui sont tous à leur propre charge. A vingt cinq (25) ans ayant acquis de l'expérience dans la vente de tissus, Véronique a commencé à vendre pour son propre compte. Aujourd'hui pour renforcer son activité, Véronique a besoin de plus de moyens financier; c'est pourquoi elle s'est adressée à ALIDé pour avoir de crédit.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ».
