Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Véronique O. was born around 1950 in Ouidah in the Atlantique province. She did not go to school. She accompanied her mother from the age of 7 while she sold cloth.

Véronique is a widow and the mother of 7 children who are all independent now. At the age of 25, having acquired experience in the sale of cloth, Véronique continued selling cloth on her own. Today, in order to bolster her business, Véronique needs funds; this is why she came to ALIDé to receive this loan. ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language, Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bolts of lining, HITAGETH fabrics, and poplin

loans.name: Abduraup

texts.ru: Абдурауп - молодой человек 24 лет, женат, но пока детей не имеет. У него среднее образование. После окончания школы изза финансовой проблемы он не смог поступить в Университет. Жена занимается производством и продажей козьей пряжи. Абдурауп занимается куплей дешевого молодого скота и откормив, через 4-5 месяцев продает скот. Таким образом он зарабатывает на жизнь, чтобы прокормить жену, и они готовятся стать родителями. Узнав у соседей что при помощи кредита можно расширить свой бизнес он решил взять займ. Абдурауп очень рад выдаче ему кредита. Он постарается использовать свой займ для получения большей прибыли.
texts.en:
Abduraup is a young man of 24, married, but has no children at the moment. He received a secondary school education, but due to financial difficulties, after graduating from school was not able to enter the university. His wife spins and sells cashmere yarn. Abduraup buys inexpensive young cattle and fattens them for sale in 4-5 months' time, and is thus able to make a living, enough to feed his wife. They are preparing to become parents. Having learned from his neighbors about using credit to expand his business, he decided to take out a loan. Abduraup is very pleased that he has been granted a loan, and he will try to use his loan to earn a good profit.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and sale of cattle

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibrahima W. est un commerçant.  Il est marie et il habite au quartier Cité Lamy à Thiès, une ville de 70 kilomètres de Dakar, le capital de Sénégal.  Il a commence son petit commerce depuis 1989.  Son activité consiste à vendre la pate d’arachide, de l’huile de palme et du gombo en poudre en gros et en détail.  Avec ce prêt il va acheter 250 kg d’arachide, 150 kg de gombo en poudre, 50 litres de l’huile de palme, et transport.  Avec ses marchandises il veut renforcer son activité dont les revenues lui permettent d’entretenir sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima W. is a businessman. He is married and lives in the Cité Lamy district in Thiès, a town 70 km from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He began his little business in 1989. His business consists in selling peanut butter, palm oil, and powdered okra, wholesale and retail. With this loan he is going to buy 250 kg of peanuts, 150 kg of powdered okra, 50 liters of palm oil, and pay for transport. With this merchandise, he will be able to bolster his business whose income allows him to support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts, palm oil, and powdered okra

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr: Kadiatou G. est mariée, 47 ans avec 7 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle tient un commerce en détail de divers produits alimentaires comme légume,pate d'arachide, huile de palme sur étal au marché. Elle a pour objectif de renforcer son capital et d’améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kadiatou G. is married, 47 years of age, and is raising 7 children. She has a little shop selling various foodstuffs such as vegetables, peanut butter, palm oil in a little stand in the market. Her goal is to bolster her working capital and improve living conditions, as well as the health of her family, and pay school fees.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of vegetables, peanut butter, and palm oil for retail sale

loans.name: Volodimir

texts.en:
Volodimir L. lives and works in Ivano-Frankivsk where he is originally from. He started his outdoor ad and marketing business about 6 years ago. Volodimir graduated from a commercial college and couldn't find a decent job anywhere. This is why he decided to launch his own venture. This enterprise has been an effective source of income for him ever since. Volodimir's monthly income is about 4,000 Grivnas.

Volodimir works many hours a day to see his business succeed. Now he's faced with a need to buy some additional oracal and plastic materials for his work. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 Grivna to purchase sufficient materials for ad panels and banner ads.

Volodimir has many challenges in his work. However, he doesn't want to be a hired employee, preferring to work for himself. He is hopeful that with hard work, determination, and financial assistance his business will continue to be successful and provide him with a stable, long-term income. One of his long-term plans is to continue expanding his business.

One interesting fact about Volodimir is his passion for soccer – he plays in one of the local teams and enjoys this hobby very much.

loans.use: To purchase additional oracal and plastic for his ad banners.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Married with six children, Monica T. supports her family by owning a restaurant in the heart of the market in Momo. She has been a GHAPE member for several years and this loan will be her fourth from the organization. This loan will allow Monica to purchase additional plates, bowls, pots, trays, spoons and oil as well as to pay taxes on the restaurant.

Monica is determined "to cook the best that [she] can," and so with that mentality and the convenient location of the restaurant, her business will continue to succeed as well as benefit her community. To keep her customers returning, she opens early when most people open their shops at the market.

On a personal note, Monica has faced many illnesses in her family and the deaths of her brother and one of her children. She and her family also struggle with her husband's sudden blindness and the financial difficulties in sending the children to school. However, she plans to use the profits of her loan to confront such challenges, by paying her children's school fees, completing construction on their house and providing better medical services for the family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy additional plates, bowls, trays, and pots, and pay taxes on her restaurant.

loans.name: Souadou

texts.fr: Souadou B. est une veuve de 46 ans avec 7 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle s’adonne à la vente de pâte d’arachide et de fruits (orange) pour subvenir aux besoins familiaux. Elle voudrait avec ce prêt renforcer son capital.
texts.en:
Souadou B. is a widow of 46 with 7 children for whom she is responsible. She sells peanut butter and fruit (oranges) to support her family. She would like to use this loan to bolster her working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of peanut butter and oranges

loans.name: Bahodurhon

texts.ru: Баходурхон Азамов мужчина 33 лет. Женат, имеет 3-х детей. Имеет высшее образование, но изза нехватки рабочих мест по его специальности он водит маршрутное такси, которое является его собственностью. Жена не работает, так как воспитывает троих детей, в том числе грудного ребенка. Баходурхон должен работать, чтоб зарабатывать на жизнь, прокормить и обучить своих детей. Баходурхон взял кредит для установки газового оборудования для своей машины. Когда он установит оборудование, заправка газа ему будет обходится дешевле, чем бензин. И прибыль будет больше.
texts.en:
Bahodurhon is a 33-year-old man. He is married and has three children. He has a college education, but due to a lack of jobs in his profession, he drives a marshrutka, which is a commercial passenger van that serves as a taxi. The van is his personal property. His wife does not work outside the home, since they have three children, one of whom is still nursing. Bahodurhon must work to earn a living to feed and educate his children. He has taken out a loan to install a natural gas fuel system on his vehicle. Once the equipment is installed, it will be cheaper to fill his tank with natural gas than it was to use gasoline, thus increasing his profit.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Owner and driver of a commercial passenger van that serves as a taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: renovating her pub

loans.name: Igor

texts.en:
Igor Z. and his wife live in Kahovka, Kherson region. His kids are grown and live separately. Igor runs a small mobile business selling construction and remodeling supplies in marketplaces in the Kherson region. He has been working in this niche of trade for 14 years. Currently he has 73,000 Hryvnia in working capital.

Igor is focused and determined. His experience working in the construction and remodeling spheres helps him to be very organized and efficient in his business. Igor is hoping to see the number of construction sites in the Ukraine increase which would subsequently stimulate development of his venture. He is seeking a loan of 6,350 Hryvnia to purchase additional construction supplies for retail sale.

We believe this client has a great potential and the current loan will only add to the success of his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional construction supplies to sell.

loans.name: Kafakh Group

texts.fr:
http://sem-fund.org/carabane.php

Nous avons fini de rembourser le premier prêt que vous nous avez accordé. Nous sommes très satisfaites et sommes venues demander à ce que cela soit renouveler, car avec ce que vous nous avez preté, nous sommes parvenues à travailler pendant toute l'année et nous avons réussi à aider nos enfant à prendre en charge leur scolarité sur le continent; Comme vous le savez, notre écovillage est très enclavé et l'accès est très difficile. C'est grâce au prêt que Kiva nous a accordé que nous avons affronter l'année scolaire de nos enfants avec beaucoup de sérénité et moins d'angoisse. Les bénéfices que nous avons tiré de l'activité précèdante nous a beaucoup soutenu. Bien que nous ne sommes pas parvenues à faire des économies; nous avons quand même pu faire face aux besoins élémentaire de nos familles. Nous comptons donc reprendre le commerce des différents produits que sont transformés ici et de vendre des ustensiles dont les populations ont besoin.
texts.en:
http://sem-fund.org/carabane.php We have finished reimbursing the first loan that you gave us. We are very pleased about that and have come to ask you to renew the loan. With the sum you loaned us, we managed to work the whole year and we were able to pay our children's school fees.

As you know, our eco-village is off in the country and hard to reach. Thanks to the Kiva loan we were able to face our children's school year with serenity and less anguish. The profit that we made from our former business sustained us.

Although we did not manage to put by any savings, we were at least able to cater for the basic needs of our families. Thus, we intend to take up a business selling different products that are produced here and sell the utensils that the inhabitants need. Note: one member of our group, Rokhaya G., was not present for the photo

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of household merchandise and  sale of ocean and forest foods

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married. She and her husband Ivan have two kids. Their family lives in Ordzhonikidze. Irina sells clothing items in the central marketplace of her home town as well as small village markets in her region. Irina’s opened her business 15 years ago. Currently, she has about 19,000 Hryvnia in working capital. Her profit amounts to 2,700 Hryvnia a month.

Irina is a hard worker. Clients always feel welcome when they come to buy from Irina because she gives each customer her full attention, and serves them politely and with respect. Reasonable pricing and a variety of inventory make her store appeal to many customers looking for a bargain. Irina realizes that lending services have helped her business grow and become self-sustainable. Irina is requesting a loan of 9,000 Hryvnia to increase her inventory. She is planning to purchase a variety of outfits that would be both durable and apealing to all of her customers. She believes that assortment of inventory at exceptionally reasonable prices will draw many new clients to her business.

loans.use: To expand merchandise

loans.name: Sounkara

texts.fr: Sounkarou K. est une femme de 31 ans, divorcée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle souhaiterait renforcer le capital de son commerce. Elle s’active dans la transformation de l’arachide en pâte afin de la vendre. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa progéniture.
texts.en:
Sounkarou K. is a woman of 31, divorced and the mother of 4 children. She would like to bolster the working capital of her business. She transforms peanuts into peanut butter which she sells. Her income permits her to improve living conditions and ensure the health and the school fees for her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: production and sale of peanut butter

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy A. is 48 years old and married with four children. Three of her children go to school. Mercy lives with her husband who is now a teacher. She is an achiever and committed to her work. She sells detergents such as toilet soap, and washing soap etc. Mercy travels to Accra to purchase her stock of goods in bulk in order to sell them at retail price. She goes door to door selling her products. She has been in this business for twenty years. She therefore request for a loan support to buy bulk supply of soaps to increase her inventory. She would be grateful for your support. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Merciful God’.

loans.use: Mercy wants the loan to buy assorted cartons of soap for supply.

loans.name: Trésor Plus Group

texts.fr: Odile N. vend de la braise dans un quartier le plus peuplé, situé au nord de Kinshasa. Son capital actuel est de $150. Son affaire génère un bénéfice de $11 par semaine. Odile a commencé sa première activité commerciale en 2000. Après s’être divorcée avec son mari en 1998, elle a traversé une période économique très difficile avec sa fillette de 8 ans. Elle a commencé son affaire avec un capital initial de $20. Son activité consistait à faire des omelettes et du thé aux clients. De 2000 à 2008, son chiffre d’affaire a atteint $200. Son capital a connu une baisse en 2009 à cause de l’instabilité de la monnaie. Le nouveau crédit a permit à  Odile  d’acheter trente sacs de braise pour revendre afin d’accroitre son bénéfice. Son rêve est d’ouvrir un dépôt de braise à livrer aux détaillants. Odile a 43 ans, divorcée et mère de quatre enfants dont une fillette de 8 ans qui étudie, habite avec elle.
texts.en:
Odile N. sells charcoal in a very populous neighborhood situated north of Kinshasa. Her present working capital amounts to US$ 150. Her business makes a profit of US$ 11 per wek.

Odile began her first business in 2000. After divorcing from her husband in 1998, she and her 8-year-old daughter came through a very difficult economic period. She began her business with an initial capital of US$ 20. She was selling omelettes and tea to her customers. From 2000 to 2008 her capital rose to US$ 200.

She had a drop in capital in 2009 due to the instability of the currency. This new loan has permitted Odile to buy 30 sacks of charcoal for re-sale so as to increase her profit. Her dream is to open a charcoal depot so as to supply retailers.

Odile is 43, divorced, and the mother of 4 children, of whom one daughter of 8 years old lives with her and is enrolled in school.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing 30 sacks of charcoal for re-sale

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas B. is a 35 year old divorced mother of four children.  Her children are currently in school.  Dorcas lives in Twifo Praso in the central region of Ghana with her children. Since the divorce, the responsibility of raising children rests of her shoulders. She is determined to provide for her children through hard work and commitment.  To support her children, she has been selling cosmetic products like spray, powder, blouses etc. and sells through hawking. Dorcas sells these cosmetics in her neighborhood to her loyal clients. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her make good income to sponsor her children’s education. She is so sure that your loan support will bring her to the desired results she expects. She belongs to the village bank called "Merciful God".

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics

loans.name: Dmytryi

texts.en:
Dmytryi is married. He lives in Kherson and sells women’s clothing at the Central market. Dmytryi’s discipline and orderly approach along with two previous loans has helped his business grow steadily over the past 5 years. Today he has about invested a large portion of his income in his business. 

Dmytryi is very gregarious and has a unique gift of understanding people and building good relationships with them. These characteristics have helped him become successful in the competitive clothing market. Dmytryi’s biggest dream is financial independence and decent livelihood for his family. He hopes the current loan will promote further growth of his business and help him see his dream come true.

loans.use: To re-stock inventory

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel G. is 37 year old father of three children. Two of his children are currently in school. He is very supportive of his wife in taking care of the children. He has operated a tailoring shop for the past twelve years, and is currently training two apprentices in sewing to equip them with skills and experience for their future careers. He sews all sorts of male and female wear with various kinds of styles; executive suits, shirts, kabas and slits, wedding dresses, funeral clothes etc. He is very creative and always want to come up with new styles. 

He wants to use the loan to buy more sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase output and efficiency. He also hopes to increase savings to support his kids through school.

loans.use: To buy more sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary F. is 60 year old married woman with four children. All of her children are currently working. She lives with her family in Twifo which is located in the central region of Ghana. For the past two years, Mary has been baking bread and other pastries in order to provide fore her family. She bakes sugar bread, wheat bread etc and retails her pastries to her customers. She makes sure her that the quality of the food meets her customer’s expectations. Her customers book their order in advance and before they arrive at her stand their order is ready. She also retails pastries to individuals for their morning breakfast through hawking which is house to house selling. The price of commodity is increasing which is making it difficult to buy more raw materials from the market. Mary needs the loan to buy more bags of flour, sugar, margarine, milk and firewood to supply her stand.

loans.use: To buy baking materials like bags of flour, sugar, margarine, yeast and firewood etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy and resell sea and forest products

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Leticia A. is a 65 year old widow and mother of five children. Unfortunately one child is dead living with four who are working. She lives at Twifo Praso in the central region of Ghana. She operates a soda fountain in her front yard. She is requesting a loan to buy assorted drinks to upgrade her inventory. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Yiedeai’ which means Wealth in Swahili.

loans.use: to increase inventory

loans.name: Komlanvi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur habite le quartier de gblinkomé, il exerce comme activité la confection de tricots sur lesquels il fait des dessins, il a ouvert à cet effet  son atelier qu’il a appelé TCHECOBA, il a commencé cette activité en 1994. La qualité de ses services fait qu’il attire tous les jours de nouveaux clients. Actuellement il a reçu  une commande d’un de ses clients mais il ne dispose pas de colorants pour faire ce travail, il sollicite alors de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 10 boîtes de colorants et des pinceaux. Il est marié et père de 02 enfants, c’est cette activité qui lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who lives in the Gblinkomé neighborhood. His business consists in knitting pullovers, on which he paints drawings. He started this business in 1994, and he opened his workshop called "TCHECOBA". Thanks to the quality of his services, he gets new customers every day. At this time, he has received an order from one of his customers, but he lacks the dyes he needs to execute the order. He's therefore seeking his first loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy 10 boxes of dye, and brushes. He's married and the father of 2 children, and this business enables him to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 boxes of dye, and brushes

loans.name: Diouromfouk Hussel 1 Group

texts.fr:
http://sem-fund.org/mlomp.php

Après avoir reçu un premier prêt qui a été renouvelé, nous sommes revenues pour demander à ce que le prêt soit reconduit, car les autres membres de notre association n'avaient pas bénéficié du premier. Cependant, nous tenons à remercier Kiva qui a fait de nous des femmes conscientes de leur capacité de production et de travailleuses qui arrivent à gagner leur vie grâce à la sueur de leur front. Nous allons donc acheter des produits bruts (huilles de palmes, pâte d'arachide, crevettes fraiches, poissons et huître) que nous allons transformer et vendre dans les grandes villes. Nous voulons aussi acheter des fruits , puisque c'est la saison pour en revendre en ville et subvenir ainsi aux besoins de nos enfants et de nos familles.
texts.en:
After receiving a first loan which was renewed, we are coming back to ask for another loan, because the other members of our association did not benefit from the first one. Nevertheless, we want to thank Kiva for making us aware of our capacity of production, and for turning us into working women who manage to provide for themselves. We will buy raw products (palm oil, peanut butter, fresh shrimps, fish and oysters), to transform them and sell them in the big cities. We will also buy fruits since they are in season, to resell them in the city. We will thus be able to provide for our children and families.

http://sem-fund.org/mlomp.php

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw food products, to transform and sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah N. is 62 years old, widowed, and the mother of seven children. Two of her children are in school, while the other two are working. She lives with her family at Twifo Praso in the central region of Ghana. She sells cooking utensils such as large cooking pots, coal containers, and ladles. She has been working at her business for twenty years. Currently, her customers are demanding more stock but she doesn’t have the current inventory to meet the heightened demand. Sarah is requesting a loan to purchase more stock, to continue to support her family and contribute her income.

loans.use: To restock her inventory

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr: Mariée à un menusier et mère de 04 enfants, madame Z. abla a ouvert depuis 2005 un bar qu’elle a appelé « ROYAL AG », son commerce marche bien surtout les week-ends. C’est cette activité qui lui permet de bien subvenir aux charges de sa famille. Elle souhaite s’approvisionner en casiers de boissons pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, pour cela elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter 25 casiers de boissons non alcoolisées et des casiers de bière
texts.en:
Married to a furniture maker and the mother of 4 children, Mrs. Z. Abla opened a bar called "ROYAL AG" in 2005. Her business is doing well, especially during the weekends, and enables her to provide for her family. She would like to resupply by buying cases of beverage, in order to better meet customer demand. She's therefore seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, to buy 25 cases on non-alcoholic beverages, as well as cases of beer.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 25 cases of non-alcoholic beverages, and cases of beer

loans.name: Aziadeko

texts.fr:
T. Aziadeko est né vers 1949 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Aziadeko est originaire de Ganvié, la cité lacustre du Bénin. Aziadeko est orphelin de père depuis son enfance et a été élevé par son oncle T. Mahuflin. Aziadeko n’est jamais allé à l’école. Aziadeko est veuf et père de huit (8) enfants : deux de ses filles sont déjà mariées, les trois autres continuent d'aller à l'école et ses trois garçons sont en apprentissage. Mais ces cinq derniers enfants sont encore à la charge de Aziadeko. C’est depuis l’âge de six (6) ans que Aziadeko accompagnait son oncle à la pêche. Après son mariage, Aziadeko a continué avec l’activité de pêche. Aziadeko a eu déjà trois crédits auprès de ALIDé. Ces crédits lui ont permis d’acheter de barque pour la pêche. Aziadeko sollicite un quatrième crédit pour renforcer son activité de pêche afin de faire plus de profit pour mieux subvenir à ses besoins et aux besoins de ses enfants. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Aziadeko T. was born circa 1949 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Aziadeko's family is from Ganvié, a lake village in Benin. He lost his father during his childhood, and was raised by his uncle Mahufin T.. Aziadeko never attended school. He's a widower and the father of 8 children : two of his daughters are already married, but he still has to provide for the other three. His three sons are apprentices.

Since he was 6 years old, he's been going fishing with his uncle. After his marriage, Aziadeko continued this business. Aziadeko already benefited from three loans from Kiva's partner, Alidé. These loans enabled him to buy small boats to go fishing. He's seeking a fourth loan to bolster his fishing business, in order to increase his profits to better provide for his children.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fishnets

loans.name: Therson

texts.en: Therson C. B. is 39 years old, he is married with four children who are all currently in school. Therson is a Hardware dealer and he sells paints, nails, roofing sheets, hammer, PVC pipes and other goods in Twifo Praos, the town where he has lived with his family for nine years. He buys his supplies from importers in the greater Accra of Ghana at wholesale prices and then sells to his customers at retail prices. Therson will use the loan to increase his stock of paints, nails, hammers, and other goods, and to accelerate the growth of his business. With the loan, he hopes to increase savings, to expand his shop, and to start selling cement. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Joyful way’, and he is very grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of assorted paints, nails, sand paper, hammers etc and to begin selling cement

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is 45 years old. She is married and a mother of five children. Currently all the children are in school. She loves selling goods as a source of livelihood.  She has been selling cereals like maize, gari, the sale of palm oil etc. for three years now. She treks to farming communities like Kintampo in the Brong Ahafo region to buy her stock of cereals in bulk from the farmers. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and retail to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy bulk supply of cereals to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school. Mary belongs to a village bank called ‘Yiedeai’ which means Wealth.

loans.use: Mary wants to buy more cereals like maize, gari and palm oil etc.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel A. A. is 32 years old and he is married and loves his work. He lives in the central region of Ghana with his wife and his two children. He has been a general photographer for the past five years. He owns a photography and video shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also goes to events like parties and concerts to take photographs of his clients. Samuel also has a store in the market where he sells cameras, flash bulbs, and video cameras. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Yiedeai’ which means Wealth and he is very thankful for the loan.

loans.use: To buy additional tools and materials like cameras, flash bulbs, and video cameras.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda A. A. is 59 years old. She is widowed with two children who currently work. Linda is very committed to her business and improving her social status. She lives at cape coast in the central region of Ghana with her family. She has been selling traveling bags, sewing machine parts, and used clothes in the central market for almost forty years. She started this business with her mother when she was a little girl and took over after her mother died. Linda hopes to  expand her business by restocking her inventory. She therefore would use this loan to buy traveling bags, sewing machines parts and clothing materials etc. and would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy traveling bags, sewing machines parts and cloths in bulk.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr: Fatoumata Kanté est une femme de 45 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle veut maintenir son activité qui consiste à vendre des crèmes, de la glace et des jus. Fatoumata vends auss des bananes. Elle compte, avec ses revenus, payer la scolarité à ses enfants.
texts.en:
Fatoumata Kanté, age 45, is married and the mother of 3 children. She wants to sustain her business consisting in selling creams, ice creams, and drinks. Fatoumata also sells bananas. With her income, she intends to pay the school expenses of her children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell creams, ice creams, and bananas

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is married and has five children. She is very supportive towards her family especially to her children.  She is 48 years old.  She runs a clothing shop and sells jeans, blouses, skirts, women slippers, kid’s wear, and dressing bags for the past twenty-two years. Rose is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs a loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance.

loans.use: To purchase ladies wears like bras, kid’s wear and slippers etc.

loans.name: Theodora

texts.en: Theodora A. is 35 years old, and married with four children. All her children are currently in school. Theodora runs a hardware business and sells paint, nails, roofing sheets, hammers, PVC pipes etc. at cape coast, a town where she has lived with her family for fifteen years now. She buys her supplies from importers in the greater Accra of Ghana. She also sells used clothing at her store. Theodora requests this loan to expand her shop to include the sale of suitcases. She would be very grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of assorted paints, nails, sand paper, hammer and used clothing etc.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy A. is a married woman of 42 years with three children currently in school. Her husband has been very resourceful in support of the children. She lives at Cape Coast in the central region of Ghana with her children. The partial responsibility of the children rests on her. She is determined to provide for her children through hard work and commitment. To support her children, she has been selling cosmetics and products such as spray, powder and London cooking utensils etc.  from a rented store at the market center. She says selling cosmetics and cooking utensils is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her make more income to sponsor her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cosmetics and cooking utensils.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary M. is 45 years old and she is married with three children. All her children are currently in school.  She lives at cape coast in the central region of Ghana. She is a trader who deals with assorted products like cooking utensils, plastic bowls, and lanterns etc. She has been trading for eighteen years now. She attracted a lot of customers who purchase from her stand. She treks to Accra to purchase her stock of goods. Recently she has been facing challenges in her business as a result of inadequate funds to buy stock. She requests a loan amount to buy more supply of the products such as cooking utensils. Which is frequently demanded by her numerous customers. With the loan she believes she will be more resourced to make a lot of profits to build a store to reduce the frequent walking in the street to sell. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: Mary wants to increase her stock of inventory like cooking utensils

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr:
A. Albertine est née le 15 novembre 1980. Albertine vend des vêtements pour bébés et petits enfants, des dessous de femmes, de sacs de sotie et des chaussures de sortie. C'est au Nigéria, pays frontalier au Bénin que Albertine va acheter ses produits et revient au Bénin, précisement à Cotonou Capitale Économique du Bénin pour les revendre. Albertine a déjà eu de ALIDé trois prêts qui lui ont permet d'amener son activité au niveau où elle est aujourd'hui. Actuellement, Albertine a pour projet de développer et de diversifier son activité. C'est pourquoi Albertine demande encore de crédit à ALIDé. Ainsi, Albertine pourra faire plus de profit pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
A. Albertine was born on November 15, 1980. She sells clothing for babies and small children, women's undergarments, handbags, and dress shoes. Nigeria, a country bordering Benin, is where she goes to buy her merchandise to bring back for resale in Benin, to Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, to be exact. Albertine has had three loans from Alidé that enabled her to operate her business at a level at which she is today. Currently, she has a plan for developing and diversifying her business. This is why she's again asking Alidé for a loan. Thus, she'll be able to make more profit to provide for her family better.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing for babies, childen, and adults, as well as shoes and handbags

loans.name: Rose Aline

texts.fr: La dame Rose Aline B. est âgée de 37 ans, mariés et mère de 2 enfants. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité de vente de crème et de glace, activité dont elle a l’expérience et qui est très rentable en cette période de chaleur. Son objectif est de soutenir son mari pour la prise en charge de leur famille.
texts.en:
Rose Aline B., age 37, is a lady who is married and the mother of two. She's requesting this loan to bolster her business selling cream and ice, a business in which she has experience and which is very profitable in this period of hot weather. Her objective is to support her husband to provide for their family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make sell cream and ice

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth B. is 62 years old. She is married and has seven children who are all currently working. Elizabeth trades traveling bags and suitcases at the local market of central market of cape coast, a town where she lives. She buys her bag supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells to her customers at retail prices. She requests a loan to increased her stock of school bags, traveling bags and suitcases. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase savings, expand her shop, and to rent a shop to house her excess goods.

loans.use: To procure increased stock of traveling bags and suitcase.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is married to Nebaseeh George Neba. They are both GHAPE beneficiaries and have four children; she lives in the heart of metropolitan town of Bamenda, Cameroon.  She plans to invest this loan in dressmaking and cultivation of ginger and cassava.  Precisely she will purchase cloth (textile) for dressmaking, ginger seed and pay for clearing and hoeing of farm for planting of ginger and cassava. Her ginger and cassava farm is located outside the main town whereas her dressmaking workshop in the town. 
 
This is Rachael’s second loan; she has been a GHAPE member since 2007.  Ginger is a medicinal plant that is very profitable, while cassava can be used to process many other products such as garri and waterfufu for marketing. She is a long time fashion designer and has many customers. 
 
With the profit from this loan, Rachael plans to buy a piece of land for her family to construct a house.  She also plans to take care of her family, ensure that they eat well and buy their medication.  She knows she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the small repayment installments.
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Cloth, Ginger Seed and Clearing of her Farm

loans.name: Pearl

texts.en: Pearl S. is 39 years old. She is married and is the mother of three children. Currently all her children are in school. Pearl trades in traveling bags, school bags and suitcases in the local market on the cape coast, which is the town she lives in. She buys her supplies of bags from importers at wholesale prices and sells to her customers at retail prices. She requests for a loan to enable her to increase her stock of traveling bags, school bags and suitcases. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase savings to expand her shop. She has been in business for eight years now.

loans.use: To procure increased stock of traveling bags and suitcase.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis B. is 35 years old, married, and has two children. All of his kids currently attend school. Francis sells a variety of hardware materials, such as paint, nails, and roofing. He has run his business for over twenty years. He purchases his supplies from importers in the greater Accra of Ghana at wholesale prices, and then resells his merchandise at retail value. Francis is extremely committed to his work and wants to increase his stock of materials to meet the increased demand for customers. He hopes to use his income to continue the schooling of his children and contribute to the family income.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Marie Joseph

texts.fr: Marie Joseph B. est mariée avec 5 enfants en charge, pour qui elle assure la dépense quotidienne. Elle fait de la vente de glace de crème et aimerait maintenir cette activité afin de mieux améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille.
texts.en:
Marie Joseph B. is married and has five children to support, covering their day-to-day expenses. She sells ice cream and would like to maintain this business in order to improve her family's living conditions in terms of health and schooling.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell ice cream

loans.name: Rosemond

texts.en:
Rosemond A. is 51 years old. She is married with five children who are currently in school due to the help of government free compulsory education for every child. However, she is still constrained with inadequate funds to make business progress.

She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, tinned tomatoes, spices, eggs, toothpaste, canned foods, toilet soap, etc. She has run this business for 22 years. Through this, she used the proceeds to cater for her household needs. She travels to Accra, which is one of the busiest markets, where she buys her stock of goods.

She deems it an opportunity to expand her business and wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, canned foods, toothpaste, etc., to increase her stock of goods available for sale. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Ebenezer’.

loans.use: To buy more supplies for her grocery shop

loans.name: Laure

texts.fr:
A. Laure est née vers 1974 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Laure est mariée à LOKO Bertin et est mère de deux enfants: Arnaude, âgée de quatre ans est à la maternelle et Aurelie deux ans. Laure est couturière mais en plus de la couture, Laure fait de la distribution de tissus, de sacs et de  chaussures. Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle Laure a besoin de plus de moyens financiers. C'est pourquoi Laure sollicite auprès de ALIDé un prêt. 


 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
A. Laure was born around 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to LOKO Bertin and is the mother of two children: Arnaude, age 4, in pre-school; and Aurelie, age 2. Laure is a seamstress. And in addition to sewing, she distributes fabrics, handbags, and shoes. To satisfy her customers better, she is in need of additional funds. That's why she's requesting a loan from Alidé.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, shoes, and sewing supplies

loans.name: Kokoé Martine

texts.fr: Madame L. habite à Adidogomé, un quartier de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle a commencé depuis 1999 le commerce de maïs et de charbons de bois.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter plus de maïs et bois.  Madame L. est mariée, et elle a trois enfants.
texts.en:
Ms L. lives in Adidogomé, a district of Lomé, the capital of Togo. In 1999, she started doing commerce in corn and in charcoal. Wanting to expand her inventory to do better in her sales and in satisfying her customer, she's requesting her first loan to buy more corn and wood. Ms. L. is married, and she has three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and charcoal

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy W., a 44 year old trader, is divorced with three children in school. She is a very resourceful woman whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family. Dorothy supports her children and provides for the household through the sale of secondhand shoes and ladies' slippers. Secondhand shoes and slippers are in demand in Ghana, as brand-new ones are very expensive for the economically active poor. The selling of secondhand shoes and slippers has created a market for many women like Dorothy.

With her loan, Dorothy wants to purchase used clothing and slippers to increase her inventory. She believes the loan will help her save for her children’s education and also to rent a store for her trade. She belongs to a village bank called Jeremiah.

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas D. is 40 years old; he is married and the father of four children. Currently all his children are in school. He is very resourceful and hard-working man who wants to leave a legacy for his children by providing for their education needs. He did not have the opportunity to attend school and he wants to correct that by providing for his children.

Thomas sells car interior decorations such as air freshers, flags, stickers, teddy bird, steering wheel covers, etc. He has been in this business for the past 15 years, taking care of the family. Thomas has a store in a Cape Coast mechanics shop where most car users bring their cars for maintenance. His goods are cheap and for that reason lots of drivers buy from his stand. He therefore requests a loan to buy more goods like air freshers, flags, stickers, etc. to upgrade his inventory. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Jeremiah’.

loans.use: To buy car interior decorations

loans.name: Rose Pulchérie

texts.fr: Rose Pulchérie B. est âgée de 49ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vend de la pâte d’arachide et son objectif est de promouvoir son activité afin de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
Rose Pulchérie B., age 49, is married and the mother of five. She sells peanut butter, and her objective is to promote her business in order to support her husband in providing for the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell peanut butter

loans.name: Neba Eveline

texts.en:
Eveline is married with two children; she lives in Ntamulung, Bamenda, in Cameroon. She plans to invest this loan in her poultry farm, and cheese business. Concretely, she plans to purchase 3 weeks old chickens, five bags of feed, medications, plantains, and oil.

This is Eveline’s second loan from GHAPE. She has been selling for quite some time and has been able to get to know her customer base and their demands. She is also happy with her business site as there are few competitors nearby.

With the profits from her ventures, she plans to reinvest in her businesses to help them grow. She hopes that one day her income will grow enough so that she will be able to help the poor increase their incomes as GHAPE and Kiva have helped her.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: chicks, feed, medication, plantains and oil

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina T. is 41 years old; she is a wife and mother of five kids who are currently in school. She is a trader and sells jeans, blouses, skirts, women's slippers and kids' wear. Amina says her working capital was provided by her husband, but is not adequate for her business. She is not able to purchase high quality products. She has realized that the demand for her goods has increased but meeting that demand requires additional capital. She needs loan support.

Amina believes the loan will help her to purchase good quality and large quantity to scale up sales. She wants to use the loan to purchase jeans, ladies' wear and slippers to increase her inventory. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Jeremiah’.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies' wear and slippers

loans.name: Léocadie

texts.fr: Léocadie D. est une femme de 55ans, mariée avec des enfants en charge. Elle souhaite renforcer son activité d’élevage porcine. Ceci pour améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Léocadie D. is a 55-year-old married woman who has children to support. She would like to bolster her business raising pigs. This is to improve her children's lives in terms of health and schooling.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To raise pigs

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana V. is 43 years old. She is married and a mother of three children. Currently, her children are in school. She is very supportive to her husband in taking care of the children. She has been operating a seamstress shop for the past sixteen years now. She has two apprentices whom she is giving training in sewing to equip them with her skills and experience for their future career.

Joana sews all sorts of female wear with various styles such as executive suits, shirts, "kaba and slit", wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. She is very creative and always comes up with new styles. She also sells men's shirts. She wants to use the loan to buy more sewing materials such as linen, thread, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to pay for her kids in school. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Jeremiah’. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing materials

loans.name: Komi Apélété

texts.fr: Monsieur A. est un enseignant, en 2007 i a laissé tomber l'enseignement et s’est lancé dans la vente de vêtements pour homme.  Il s’approvisionne en Europe, et il vend les vêtements dans sa boutique de prêt à porter à Protestant, un quartier de Lomé la capitale du Togo.son activité marche bien, son stock actuel ne lui permet pas de répondre à la demande actuel de sa clientèle.ayant besoin de se réapprovisionner pour satisfaire ses clients il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter plus de vêtements.  Monsieur A. est marié à une coiffeuse, et ils ont deux enfants.
texts.en:
Mr. A. is a teacher. In 2007, he left teaching and got started in selling men's clothing. He gets his supplies in Europe and sells the clothing in his read-to-wear shop in Protestant, a district of Lomé, the capital of Togo. His business is doing well. Right now his inventory prevents him from responding to the current demands of his customers. Needing to restock, so as to satisfy his customers, he's requesting his first loan from WAGES. Mr. A. is married to a hairdresser, and they have two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Hamamata

texts.en:
Hamamata L. is 36 years old. She is divorced and the mother of two children; one has completed senior high and is awaiting his results whilst her last born is still in school.

Hamamata is resourceful and enterprising. She operates a local restaurant and sells local foods like "diewuo". Diewuo is prepared from powdered maize mixed with dried cassava powder taken with soup. It is enjoyed as breakfast and lunch and normally it is prepared by the Muslims who live in the Zongo communities in Ghana.

She has a strategic business location, giving her favorable sales. She needs the loan to enable her to inject additional working capital into the business to scale up production and increase her income level. With the loan, she wants to purchase more raw materials like maize powder, cassava powder, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to facilitate her food production. Hamamata belongs to a village bank called Jeremiah. She would grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials like maize powder, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Célestine

texts.fr:
D. Célèstine est née vers 1972 à Abomey dans le Département du Zou au Centre du Bénin. Célèstine est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Célèstine vend des bidons et bouteilles vides. En effets, Célèstine passe de maison en maison pour racheter ces bidons et bouteilles vides aux ménages. Après, Célestine se rend au grand marché international du Bénin pour livrer ces produits. Célestine a déjà eu deux crédits de ALIDé qu'elle a bien remboursé. Cependant, le fonds de commerce de Célestine ne lui permet pas de mieux s'approvisionner afin de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Célestine sollicite un nouveau crédit à ALIDé. 


 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
D. Célèstine was born around 1972 in Abomey, in Zou County in central Benin. She is married and the mother of three. Célèstine sells empty cans, drums, and bottles. She actually goes from house to house to re-purchase these empty household containers. Afterwards, she goes to the grand international marketplace of Benin to deliver these goods. Célèstine has had two Alidé loans before and indeed repaid them. Yet her working capital prevents her from supplying herself better in order to satisfy her customers. That is why she's requesting a new loan from Alidé.

ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. ALIDÉ offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy empty drums and bottles

loans.name: Bih Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with seven children and lives in Ntamulung, Bamenda, in Cameroon. Elizabeth runs a small "buy and sell" provision store in her compound at Ntamulung. With this loan, she plans to buy five bags of rice, three bags of pig feed, and the clearing and hoeing of farm food crops for market. Her business plan shows she will invest 50,000 CFA (approximately $100 USD) of her own savings as well.
 
This will be Elizabeth's second loan from GHAPE. She has been quite successful in the past with her “buy and sell” business due to her location in the quarter and her reasonable prices. She purchases most of her products where they are much cheaper in bulk, and retails them at her store. She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales. 
 
With the profits from this loan, Elizabeth plans to send her children to school and support them after school. She will also consider buying more piglets for her pig farm. Her profits will also provide her with the security of knowing she can afford hospital bills and health costs.

About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy rice and pig feed and the clearing and hoeing of farm food crops for market

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: Léocadie D. est une femme de 55ans, mariée avec des enfants en charge. Elle souhaite renforcer son activité d’élevage porcine. Ceci pour améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Léocadie D., age 55, is married and has children to support. She would like to bolster her business, consisting in raising porcine livestock, in order to improve the living and health standard of her children, as well as their schooling.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make and sell peanut butter

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah A. is a 38-year-old trader. She is divorced with four children. She has sold used clothes in a local market of Cape Coast, in the Central Region of Ghana, for ten years now. With the income from her business, Hannah is supporting two of her kids in senior high school, while the eldest is learning to drive. Her major business challenge over the years has been finding sufficient funds to enlarge the business, especially in this crucial time for the economy. She has lots of marketing experience, and is very confident that the loan would enable her to achieve remarkable progress for her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes and kids' wear to serve her customers. She hopes to save enough to support her kids to the tertiary level of education. With the loan, she believes she can rent a store to conduct her business, rather than sitting by the road side. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Psalm 23.’

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes and kids' clothing

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac A. is 31 years old. He is married, and the father of three kids who are currently in school. He trades and resides at Cape Coast in the Central Region of Ghana. He operates a clothing shop where he sells men's and women's clothing, including jeans, blouses and skirts, women's slippers, dressing bags and headscarves. Isaac has been in business for fifteen years now, but he is constrained by the need for funds to run the business. He needs the loan to enable him to inject more working capital into the business, in order to scale up its progress. He believes the loan will help him upgrade his inventory, by supplying the resources to purchase items of good quality in large quantity. With the loan, he wants to purchase jeans, shirts, ladies' wear, headscarves and slippers. It is his desire to provide a better education for his children, and believes he can fulfill that through your loan support. He belongs to the village bank called Great Commission.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, shirts, ladies' wear, headscarves and slippers

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with three children and lives in Ntamulung, Bamenda, in Cameroon. Margaret runs a small "buy and sell" stand in Nkwen Market.  With this loan, she plans to invest in more products to sell at her stand.  Some of these products include rice, onions, groundnut oil, beans, tomatoes, salt, palm oil, and soybeans.  Her business plan shows she will invest 50,000 CFA of her own savings as well.  
 
This will be Margaret's second loan from GHAPE.  She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location (right on the main Market), the variety of her products, and her reasonable prices.  She purchases most of her products where they are much cheaper, and sells them at her stall.  For many customers in her community, this saves the transportation costs and the time of going to Bamenda themselves to purchase these items.  She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales. 
 
The profits from this loan will be used for the school fees of Margaret's children. Also, she plans to reinvest in her businesses to help it grow. Margaret does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments as they are quite small repayments every two weeks.  
 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Provisions for store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sacks of corn and tapioca

loans.name: Bake Tinkouwe

texts.fr: Bake Tinkouwe a pour activité  la vente d’objets en plastique et de produits de beauté.  Elle a commencé ce commerce en 2005.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 20 seaux, 20 bassines, 50 gobelets, 1 carton de plats, 40 glacières et 1 carton de pommades.elle habite à Agoe, un quartier au nord de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle et mariée, et elle a un enfant.
texts.en:
Bake Tinkouwe's business consists in selling plasticware and cosmetics. She started this business in 2005. Eager to bolster her stock in order to increase her sales, and to better meet customer demand, she's seeking her first loan. She intends to use it to buy 20 buckets, 20 basins, 50 cups, 1 box of trays, 40 coolers, and 1 box of ointments. Bake Tinkouwe lives in Agoe, a neighborhood in the north of Lomé, the capital of Togo. She's married and has one child.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell plasticware and cosmetics

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Madame KIDE-MOKAFO habite à Agoe, un quartier au nord de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle et mariée à un chauffeur de taxi, et ils ont 3 enfants.  Madame ADJAMAGO a pour activité  la vente d’oignons, un commerce qu’elle a commencé en 2005.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 6 sacs d’oignons.
texts.en:
Ms. KIDE-MOKAFO lives in Agoe, a district in norther Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is married to a taxi driver, and they have three children. Her work involves selling onions. It's a business she started in 2005. Wanting to expand her inventory, so as to do better in her sales and in satisfying her customers, she's requesting her first loan to buy six sacks of onion.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy onions to sell

loans.name: Goudjo

texts.fr: Monsieur D. a pour activité la vente de poissons et de poulets congelés.  Il a ouvert sa boutique qui s’appelle « Ets Don de Dieu » en 2005 à Avedji, un quartier de Lomé la capitale du Togo.présentement son stock de marchandises est épuisé,voulant se réapprovisionner il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit  qui lui permettrai d’acheter 2 cartons de poulets, 3 cartons d’ailes de poulets et 3 cartons de poissons. Monsieur D. a deux enfants qu’il pourra mieux soutenir avec l’augmentation de ses ventes.
texts.en:
Mr. D. sells frozen fish and chickens. He opened his shop called "Ets Don de Dieu" in 2005 in Avedji, a district of Lomé, the capital of Togo. Presently, his stock of merchandise is exhausted. Wanting to stock up again, he's requesting his first loan from WAGES. The loan will enable him to buy 2 boxes of chicken, 3 boxes of chicken wings, and 3 boxes of fish. Mr. D. has two children he'll be able to support with the increase in his sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy frozen fish and chickens

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy cloth, shoes, bags, and clothing

loans.name: Fankjah

texts.fr: Madame W. a pour activité  la vente de produits américains, plus particulièrement les médicaments et les cosmétiques génériques.  Elle a commencé à vendre ses produits de sa maison en 2005.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter des produits américains de la marque Forever et d’autres produits cosmétiques.  Madame W. habite à Sogbossito, une banlieue de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.  Elle et mariée, et elle a 3 enfants.
texts.en:
Fankjah's business is selling American products, particularly generic medicines and cosmetics. She began selling these products out of her home in 2005. Wishing to expand her stock so as to make more sales and better satisfy the demand of her clientele, she is requesting her first loan to buy American products of the Forever brand and other cosmetic products. Fankjah lives in Sogbossito, on the outskirts of Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is married and has 3 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of health products for re-sale

loans.name: Ayawovi

texts.fr: Mademoiselle D. a appris la couture, elle et une demoiselle très dynamique qui travaille dur pour subvenir à ses charges. N’ayant pas trouvé de moyens pour ouvrir son propre atelier, elle a entamé la vente de mèches en détail et la vente d’autres outils de couture.  Elle a commencé ce commerce en 2008.  Le stock dont elle dispose présentement ne lui permet pas de répondre à la demande de la clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter des mèches et d’autres outils de couture pour mieux vendre et satisfaire ses clients.  Mademoiselle D. habite à Kegue, un quartier de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.
texts.en:
Miss Ayawovi learned to be a seamstress. She is a very energetic young woman who works hard to take support herself. Not having been able to find the means to open her own workshop, she began selling hair extensions retail and also sewing supplies. She began this business in 2008. Her present inventory does not allow her to respond to the demand of her clientele, so she is requesting her first loan to buy hair extensions and sewing notions so as to make more sales and satisfy her customers. Miss Ayawovi lives in Kegue, a district of Lomé, the capital of Togo.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hair extensions and sewing implements

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr: Aïssatou CAMARA est âgée de 44 ans, mariée avec 5 enfants en charge. Elle souhaite ce prêt afin de renforcer son activité de vente d’huile de palme, de pâte d’arachide ainsi que  de légumes. Elle pourra ainsi améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille.
texts.en:
Aïssatou C., 44, is married and raising 5 children. She has asked for this loan so as to bolster her little business selling palm oil, peanut butter, and vegetables. She will thus be able to improve living conditions and the health of her family and make sure school fees get paid.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase and re-sale of palm oil, peanut butter, and vegetables

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Madame E. a pour activité  la vente de bijoux et de pagnes, un commerce qui est très rentable au Togo car beaucoup de personnes surtout les femmes l’utilisent pour confectionner les habits.  Madame E. a commencé ce commerce en 1998.  Voulant agrandir son stock pour mieux vendre et pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter des pagnes et des bijoux.  Madame E. habite avec son mari à Awatamé, un quartier de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.
texts.en:
Ms. Abra sells costume jewelry and "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), a business which is very lucrative in Togo because many people, especially women, use this cloth to make clothing. Ms. Abra began this business in 1998. Wishing to expand her inventory so as to make more sales and better satisfy the demand of her clientele, she is requesting her first loan to buy "pagnes" and jewelry. Ms. Abra lives with her husband in Awatamé, a district of Lomé, the capital of Togo.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of pagnes and costume jewelry for re-sale

loans.name: Diaraye

texts.fr: Diaraye S. est une femme mariée de 36 ans, mère de 5 enfants. Elle s’active au commerce de pâte d’arachide et aimerait renforcer son activité. Ceci pour assurer à ses enfants des conditions de vie meilleure.
texts.en:
Diaraye S. is a married woman of 36, the mother of 5 children. She sells peanut butter and would like to bolster her business. This is in order to ensure that her children have better living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: preparation and sale of peanut butter

loans.name: Rafiq

texts.en: Rafiq A. is a 38 year old trader who's been selling different foodstuffs since 2001. Rafiq is married and has one adorable daughter. He has dedicated his life to her and does his best to provide her with the best education and living conditions. Rafiq has applied for a $3000 US loan to purchase more foodstuffs for his store to increase his stock.

loans.use: To purchase more items for a store

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama D. est une mère de famille qui a en charge ses 02 enfants ainsi que 5 de ses petits fils. Elle vend sur étal divers produit alimentaire (pate d'arachide , légumes etc) et souhaiterait promouvoir son activité avec ce prêt. Son objectif est de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mariama D. is the mother of a family and raising 2 of her children as well as 5 of her grandchildren. She has a little display where she sells various foodstuffs (peanut butter, vegetables, etc.) and she would like to reinforce her business with this loan. Her goal is to support her family better.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of various foodstuffs

loans.name: Axadbek

texts.ru: Недавно Ахадбеку исполнилось 30 лет.  Ранее он выезжал на заработки в Россию, но постепенно заработка стало меньше и он решил приехать в Таджикистан. На накопленные деньги Ахадбек решил начать свой собственный бизнес. Начал с купли продажи сухофруктов, но потом решил приспособить маленькое помещение у себя дома и завез туда продукты питания. В том районе где он живет нет такого магазина и поэтому его магазин приобрел популярность и постоянных клиентов. Ахадбек женат и у него маленький ребенок. Ахадбек узнал о программе кредитования КИВА и решил подать заявку на займ для расширения своего бизнеса.
texts.en:
Axadbek recently turned 30 years old. He used to take jobs in Russia, but gradually the number of jobs has decreased and he decided to come home to Tajikistan. With the money he saved, Axadbek decided to open his own business. In the beginning he sold dried fruit, but then decided to convert a small room in his house and stocked groceries. There are no stores in the neighborhood where he lives so his store has gained popularity and regular customers. Axadbek is married and has a small child. He learned about Kiva's credit program and decided to submit an application for a loan in order to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand his grocery store

loans.name: Qıztamam

texts.en: Qıztamam R. is 50-year-old widow who has sold women's shoes in the streets of Imishli for the past three years. When her husband passed away, Qıztamam and her son were left without any means of surviving. With her son studying at the university, selling shoes is the family's only source of income. Qıztamam tries very hard to succeed, but she cannot pay rent and has to stay in the street selling her goods even if it is snowing or raining.  Luckily, the owner of the shop next to her display, which is one of the biggest stores in town, allows her to keep her goods in his shop for the night. Qıztamam would like to enlarge her business and purchase additional shoes to sell. She believes one day she could rent a good place in the central market. Qıztamam is counting on your help.

loans.use: to purchase women's shoes

loans.name: Safiou

texts.fr: Monsieur D. est soudeur, il a ouvert son atelier en 2003.  Les matériaux de travail dont il dispose actuellement sont vétustes et ne lui permettent pas d’exécuter correctement les commandes de ses clients. Il sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 5 feuilles de tôle, 4 paquets de baguettes, 5 tubes, et autres matériels de soudure.  Monsieur D. habite a Agoe, un quartier au nord de Lomé, la capitale du Togo.
texts.en:
Mr. D. is a welder who opened his workshop in 2003. The implements that he presently has at his disposal are worn out and do not allow him to prepare his customers' orders correctly. He is requesting his first loan to buy 5 sheets of corrugated iron, 4 packets of baguettes, 5 tubes, and other welding material. Mr. D. lives in Agoe, a district in the north of Lomé, the capital of Togo.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of material for his welding business

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana M. is a young and energetic woman of 22 years. She supports herself by working as a clerk in a perfume shop, a job she has held since she was 18 years old. Her family is disadvantaged and Svetlana decided to help them by working. After doing so for the last four years, Svetlana decided to open a small stall in the same shop and start selling her own goods. She has applied for a $2525 loan for this purpose.

loans.use: purchase new items for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of sacks of cereals, yams, and baskets of cheese for re-sale

loans.name: Mariama Aliou

texts.fr: Mariama Aliou D. est mariée, 41 ans et mère de 5 enfants. Avec ce prêt, elle voudrait renforcer son activité qui consiste à la transformation de l’arachide en pâte afin de la vendre. Elle a pour objectif d’améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mariama Aliou D., 41, is married and the mother of 5 children. With this loan, she would like to bolster her little business which consists in transforming peanuts into peanut butter for sale. Her goal is to improve the living conditions and health of her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: preparation and sale of peanut butter

loans.name: Arshad

texts.en: Arshad K. is 52-year-old trader who keeps his own food store in the small village of Imishli. He has run this business for over 15 years. Arshad is married and has two sons. He wants them to become successful entrepreneurs in the future and eventually take over his business. Arshad does his best to make his business as successful as possible. He would like to expand his shop and increase number of goods he sells. To fulfill this goal he has applied for a $3000 loan.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for his store.

loans.name: Konul

texts.en: Konul A. is 35-year-old woman who sells perfumes in the village of Imishli. She is a widow and lives with her parents. Konul has worked in her shop since 2005. She rents her space and purchases all her goods from the city of Baku, 3 hours away from her home town. Konul is applying for a $2000 loan to diversify the goods she sells. Let's do our best to help this hardworking woman.

loans.use: Diversify the products she sells

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en: Teymur A. is a 31-year-old trader who sells goods for home repair. He sells a wide variety of goods, which is why his store is always full of customers. Teymur's business, which he's run for the past four years, is the sole source of support for his wife and his two adorable daughters. The shop is his family's only source of income.  Teymur has applied for a $3000 loan so he can diversify his store and increase the number of items he stocks.
